If you're not sure about committing the money to play the game, try out the demo.  What the demo unfortunately lacks is the extra stuff from the "Ultimate" version of the game - online multiplayer/co-op games, different boss types, more coherent enemy formations.  It makes the game tougher, but it is a helluva lot more fun.

Biggest flaw of the game is that it can get repetitive, fast.  There's not much variety in the enemies, and while the flashing lights ARE pretty, they'll eventually start to hurt your eyes, and some of the disortions make it hard to see important things like incoming missiles, bullets, and enemies.

Still, as dirt cheap as it is now, it's worthwhile.

Photosensitive Seizure Warning
A very small percentage of people may experience a seizure when exposed to certain visual images, including flashing lights or patterns that may appear in video games. Even people who have no history of seizures or epilepsy may have an undiagnosed condition that can cause these "photosensitive epileptic seizures" while watching video games.

These seizures may have a variety of symptoms, including lightheadedness, altered vision, eye or face twitching, jerking or shaking of arms or legs, disorientation, confusion, or momentary loss of awareness. Seizures may also cause loss of consciousness or convulsions that can lead to injury from falling down or striking nearby objects.

Immediately stop playing and consult a doctor if you experience any of these symptoms. Parents should watch for or ask their children about the above symptoms - children and teenagers are more likely than adults to experience these seizures.

Beat Hazard, in its current state, is just fun. Few frills and straight to the point, this game does what you'd think and delivers on its promise. So, if you're looking to kill time in between more expansive titles or feel you're not exploiting your music collection enough, this is almost a no-brainer.

Beat Hazard, like Audiosurf, uses your own music to create gameplay. Although unlike Audiosurf, it's less like Tetris and more like Asteroids. Bad guys come at you from all directions and you shoot at them. Why? Nobody knows. What we do know is that during intense sections of music, your primary weapon becomes an extremely powerful harbinger of epilepsy. While during the slow sections it is nothing more than a pea shooter. There are also boss fights which happen at set intervals in a song. All in all, an awesome shoot-em-up. Goes extremely well with a rocking music collection.

Grab pick-ups like Volume and Power to increase the visual intensity and in turn, the power of your weapons. Max them out to become a 'beat hazard' granting an extra powerful beam of to your shots. Pick up multiplier bonus' to increase the amount of score earned from your kills.

Just calling this a music-inspired 2D shoot'emup does not do the game justice. Yes, the gameplay is fairly sober: a handful of different enemies, a half dozen different bosses, power-ups. bombs, multipliers... It's all very standard stuff. But the presentation of this standard stuff is positively bathed in amazing and seizure-inducing visuals. 

These visuals are not only influenced by your music, but by how well you play. Score more Volume power-ups and colours get more vibrant and the music plays louder. Max out your volume bar and become a Beat Hazard and give epileptic fits to all seizure sensitive people within visual range of your screen.

All in all, this game is definitely worth checking out, there's a demo available that lets you play five songs. I can guarantee you that if you play the demo, you'll be pleasantly surprised. Or you'll get a headache. Either or.

I suspect like many others, I only got this as part of an indie bundle during the recent apocalyptic sales. Twin-stick shooters are ten-a-penny these days, and for every Geometry Wars and Smash TV there's a dozen or so mediocre or downright offensive pretenders.

The procedural, music-based nature of this game, while novel and genuinely noticeable, isn't what makes this worth your time - at least, not by itself. The feel of this game is just right, and there are numerous gimmicks and tricks to be picked up, as well as a nicely absorbing reward system. It's a score-junkie's psychedelic wet dream.
The ship sprites are a bit on the rough side, but that's pretty much my only major gripe with what is otherwise an utterly worthy utter waste of your time.

A dual-stick gamepad is sort of a pre-requisite for this to be any fun, obviously enough.

Beat Hazard is Asteroids on crack and set to music. It can get quite challenging and is also a good bit of fun, allowing you to pipe in your own tunes that will affect the progression of the level. Everything about the game is well done, but it feels a bit too thrown together; and again, in many respects an Asteroids clone. The algorithm that spawns enemies based on what music you choose likewise seems a bit questionable, and many songs I tried out didn't really elicit battles that I felt fit with the rhythm of the music. I'd end up lazily floating about picking off weak enemies during adrenaline pumping electric guitar solos.

I wouldn't say it's a bad game, but I don't think I'd really recommend it to people either. It's a cool concept, but what was delivered was merely passable; nothing to get terribly excited about.

I'm so sad about this :<

I've tried giving this game a chance 2 times now. To me it's just a visualizer software that reacts to the music with merely particle effects. I would have wanted the enemy patterns be spawned in sync with the beat to make the game feel more reactive to your music (Tried different genres: metal, house, techno, ambient). Right now it just feels that the music and gameplay are in completely different layers and that doesn't work for me.

One could argue that there is some spawns reacting to the music but it doesn't feel that way. Often times you get bored and frustated when you start thinking all the things the game could have been. The spawns are too vague and unresponsive. I feel the main intent in design was to analyze the song length, create some sort of an enemy buildup into that timeframe and then spawn enemies with an intensifying interval towards the end. It's not a really elaborate system but a really generalized one.  It doesn't feel reactive to the music or feel particularly interesting.

Here are a few examples that I wanted to see: 
*Having the enemy sprites pulse to the beat at times and giving you extra stuff if destroyed in a swollen state.
*Having different enemy types pulse to different beats in the music.
*Having certain archtypes of beat sequences built to the system. For example in house music the rythm, buildup and lead are quite predictable, those could be used as standardized information and made into gameplay events.
*Every hi-hat spawning a small single enemy from a corner starting from top left and ending in bottom right.
*Every bass hit it could spawn a round pattern of small popcorn enemies etc. 

Maybe if the core gameplay were more engaging, I would not have cared about enemy beat sync, meaning the lack thereof, that much. Right now I don't feel like it really holds it's own though. It feels there are many enemy archtypes that could be used to make the gameplay more engaging and less predictable.

Also the enemy sprites look clumbsy and lack animation which gives me a somewhat unfinished feeling while playing. They stick out.

To me this game was not enjoyable due to lack of polish and expectations not being met.

If I had to chose just one word for this game it would be 'cluttered'.  Even with the visual effects turned down to the lowest you still can't see what going on.  Every explosion ends up just obscuring the screen so you can't see anything, worse is the level's music makes these unnecessary effects even more flashy and annoying.  You'll die more often than not to bullets or foes that where hidden by these effects. If they could be turn them off this game would have no challenge what so ever.

Speaking of the music, this game's soundtrack is standard issue techno crap, it sounds like it came right out of 2003.  The whole thing where your own tracks make new levels, that sucks too.  The only think music determines is how much of the screen you can't see.  I have notice that the enemy waves follow the same pattern if you use the same song, so it does have some factor but  couldn't tell you how it works.  Every time I tried one of my own tracks what happened on the screen didn't match the beat or tone or anything at all.  Hell, half the songs I tried had absolutely nothing was going screen for 10-15 seconds.

Doesn't waste you money on this game, get a real bullet storm game, like Ikaruga.

This game is built on a brilliant concept. If you ever thought "Dude, this would be way better with a different soundtrack..." this is the answer to your prayers. It's like the old days of Raptor: Call of the Shadows and Asteroids, but at the same time, it's got enough of all the modern conveniences to keep stuff interesting. 

As a rythym game, the soundtrack is custom to you, but even the built in tracks are pretty good. Ship designs are imaginative and some of the options for building your own custom ships are great (autofire ftw)! The community has put together a bunch of classics like the Millenium Falcon, Enterprise and, of course, Raiden.

I'm going to keep playing this for as long as I'm adding tracks to my music collection!

If you're a musically oriented person and enjoy the prospect of a twin-stick shooter in sync with any song of your choosing, then you'll probably love this. As long as there's songs in my library then I'll never tire of this game. And there's so many achievements, ranks, DLC bonuses, ships, ship editor, etc. that it's virtually impossible to feel like you've done everything. This game offers me the chance to listen to my music AND feel like a badass, dodging countless bullets and debris while listening to the sounds of a soft Native American flute or the intense death-growls of Amon Amarth's Johan Hegg. It's just pure fun.

      Once you put some decent hours in, you'll  become a true-blooded space-beast slayer. The more time you put in the funner it gets, because you unlock perks and use the well-balanced money system to upgrade them over time. The achievements keep you busy; your songs keep you goin'; this game keeps you satisfied!

Warning: The game containts a lot of flashing lights. So to those who have epilepcy, turn away from this game immediatly for your health and avoid having a seizer.

The good: Use any music to play the game rather from your PC, internet radio, or even seach a track to find and play on from the in game menu. Each track you play has their own veriety of enemies, mini-bosses, and bosses. So each track you play will have different enemies. The game also has a lot of power ups, weapons, ships, and upgrades you can earn on this game by ranking up with high scores. The game also has local and online co-op. So have a friend you can play and listen to the music you both enjoy. There's some additional challenges from the ships you play to unlock more ships, and/or to rank up your secondary rank. Additionally, there is also the Steam Workshop added to this game. So there is a lot of custom ships and ship skins you can play around with.

The bad: It will feel very repeatative if you don't have a lot of tracks to play on. It might start to get easier the more upgrades you get, making the harder difficulties feel like a cake walk if you're good at these type of games. Sometimes the flashing effects can be annoying when dodging the red bombs you can't blow up with normal fire.

....All I can say is, buy this game. Especially if this game is on sale. Get it immediatly. If you enjoy listening to music and playing a game at the same time like any other game you play, here you go. And if you got friends who play this game and want them to listen to the music you're playing on this game, then this is for you and everyone. Although I recommend taking a few breaks from playing this game. The flashing lights and strobe effects can be fun to look at. But after a few repeated playthroughs, I started to feel phiscally sick to my stomach and needed a break after playing it too much. Above all, it's fun to kill time and listen to music.

Of all the games that use your music library to create a stage to play on, Beat Hazard tops the list.  It's not just a simple platformer or racing game like the others, but it is instead a side-scrolling shooter where your enemies, their strength, and your power-ups are determined by the songs you play.

Combine this with good support for multiple file types and internet radio, and you've got a fun casual game that uses music really well for some dynamic gameplay.  Pick this game up if you want a fun side-scrolling shooter to play with your music!

Cons:

1) Searching for songs on your pc takes ages.

2) Out of tens of thousands songs on my pc i usually had only a hundred (most of the times less) or so matches with other players.

3) Its just too bright and colourful in my opinion. I do not suffer from epilepsy but at times i've got dizzy and my eyes simply got tired from all those unnecessary explosions of dazzling vomit.

I would still recommend it for those who do not own audiosurf 1 or 2, or got friends to play with (you will need those, because its already dead and you can hardly find any matches online).

Beat Hazard is a true gem in the widths of indie games. Basically being only a programme that analyses the amplitudes of a music track and thus sending various enemies at your laser-equipped space ship in a 2D top down view, it takes full effect after hours and hours of playing it casually.

Alongside gaming skyscrapers like Crysis or Counter-Strike, it's the tiny pizza stall in between where you go from time to time - like, casually. You feel the need, the motivation to just play a round of it, from time to time - not for long, just a few good tracks, and that's it. Until your next visit, in a few days.

Besides, Beat Hazard has developed (or has been developed) continously. It started as the basic game and received two major updates, both the two boosting the game's variability and extent, giving it new game modes, bosses, enemies and the ability of creating own ships (Shadow Operations Unit DLC). And while it was growing, it never lost its easy-to-learn usability.

Everyone interested in music should give this a try - it doesnt matter if you're going casual in this or seek a challenge for there are lots of leaderboards to improve on. And yes, if you haven't heard of it yet: Better get some sunglasses. Just in case :)

I love Beat Hazard, and I'm not really a fan of twin stick shooters. I bought the game because it had an interesting premise, and I loved the game because it really succeeds in turning that premise into a great time. Beat Hazard has almost a Guitar Hero/Rock Band feel without the gimmicky side effect; it is a game that will have you playing for hours just because "oh, (song name) had a great beat for this! I want to try (song name)!" And this is as your spouse/friends/family is sitting beside you, watching you play while asking incessantly, "Can I try? Can I try?"

The playability is literally endless. Literally. Music will always exist and new music will continue to be made, and you can play this game to the beat of said music via the form of mp3s (among others) and streaming. Be prepared to download songs you never wanted to admit liking just to try them out in the game. Be surprised as you find that certain songs offer you more challenge than you thought they would. 

When Beat Hazard claims the gameplay flows with the music, they're not just saying that. The beat picks up, the enemies fly faster, the colors get brighter, the bullets shoot faster. This offers a new level of strategy unheard of in other games, because if you know the song you are playing well, you'll know when it picks up and slows down and you can play accordingly. 

A few last positives before I end the review. The game tracks your high scores for each song that you have (for downloads, at least, I haven't tried with streaming). The game is easy to learn and great fun even for those (like me) who don't tend to like twin stick shooters. Great to launch at parties/get togethers/game nights. Great game to jump in/out of if you only have a few minutes to spare gaming. Multiple modes and unlockables. "Just one more" type of gameplay. Can be humorous at times to watch the enemy ships react to the music. It's actually kind of cute to watch them all quickly file onto the screen in a song that picks up quickly after a slow start, as if they all were sleeping off the screen until the blaring beat shook them to consciousness.

Overall, great game. I'm giving it a 10/10. Buy it if you like music. ;)

A music driven game that thrives on the thrills of shmups! blasting enemies at the speed of the song currently playing, you can up the level of difficulty with not just the regular game but also with the DLC "Ultra". It seems tolerable and not as bad on the eyes at that rate, while still keeping the effects it gives off.

A plus is being able to use your OWN music! :D

As a Bullet Hell Shooter, it's one of the smoothest I've played, and doing it to my music is really fun. However, the ultimate 'thumbs down', however tentative (consider this a 6/10), is because the game pisses me off so goddamn much.

Mainly it's the Shadow Missions; they're just way too unforgiving. As in, 'you will probably wake up covered in someone's blood' levels of unforgiving. Say, for example, a Shadow Mission saying "Beat 3 Songs on Insane Difficulty." Fine.

Songs only count if they're 3:30+ long. Fine.

If you die ONCE during this song (considering you have like 5 lives from the outset so if you're any good you should seldom fail a mission) it won't count towards your mission progress.

This is where you're gonna get angry. REALLY angry. You could get to the last 10 seconds of a song and die to a missile you couldn't see due to the game's patented Seizure-o-vision, and the game will flip you the bird and your time will have been wasted. If it was an instant game over when you died, it would be a bit more bearable, but as it is? You're gonna swear, you're gonna break stuff, you're gonna fantasize about meeting the people who designed these missions and kicking them repeatedly in the crotch.

Back to the topic of the flashing lights, I started getting a headache within SECONDS of hitting the goddamned MAIN MENU. The photosensitive seizure warning at the start doesn't do justice to just how much eyestrain you're gonna experience. On top of that, the obnoxious flashing lights make it near impossible to see the, say, red glowing seeker mines or the tiny missiles that'll kill you and give a solid 'F U' to your current Shadow Mission.

I'm perfectly fine with games being difficult, so long as they're FAIR. Super Meat Boy is fair. Dark Souls is fair. In both of those games, when you die, it's YOUR FAULT. Here, though, you could die to something you couldn't even SEE through the flashing lights, and the game will essentially kneecap you.

I'm sorry but, for whatever fun I was having, I'm more likely to remember my foaming rage than I am to remember any enjoyment.

Beat Hazard! BEAT HAZARD! Beat... hazard? This game takes your music, or their music, or someone else's music from the world wide web radio, and lets you blow things up! With pretty and dazzling colors to boot. It's fun for a good while, but without the DLC and the mysterious Shadow Missions this game would probably lose its lustre very quicky. Like a ripe avocado turning brown after being cut for a while. Y'all get my drift.

I have a thing for music games, geometry wars, and asteroids.  Effectively, Beat Hazard is a ombination of all of those things.

Because the gameplay is generated by your music your mileage may vary by a lot.  This isn't like Audiorsurf, where each song is playable if boring: certain songs are not playable at all.  The reason behind this is that sometimes nothing can happen in the song you're playing, or worse, monsters might spawn just before you hit a slow point.  The biggest issue with this game is that the music not only dictates monster spawns but also has a direct influence on your basic attack: You will not be able to kill things during quieter parts of the song.  This is absolutely game breaking at times.

Still, if you know that you can avoid the problem, and honestly I really like the gameplay.  Beat Hazard has changed a lot over the years, to the point that I don't really recognize it from when I first played it.  There's an overall level up system and some perks, but they're not so important to the gameplay (at least that's my opinion).

Unlike audiosurf this is hardly a chillout game.  This isn't something that I'll boot up when I just want to listen to music and maybe have something to do in the background: the gameplay gets pretty intense at times.  It's not necessarily difficult, but it does remind me of how harrowing geometry wars can get.

I like this game but I don't play it very often, and gameplay isn't so different between songs that it feels unique.  For the most part each song plays out pretty similarly, which is good and bad.

At the end of the day I think you should have this in your library.

Oh, but the fucking ad that pops up as you're closing the game?  The one that reverses the accept and cancel buttons?  That screen can fuck off.  Press A to exit, press a to exit, PRESS A TO GO BACK TO THE FUCKING MAIN MENU AND START AGAIN.  Gets me every god damned time.

The game is space ships, shooting shit, and evasive skills played to your own music--like Gradius for the NES on steroids at a rave but designed around the beat you choose with the ability to master different ships and gain perks to become more powerful!

Don't forget to hit the hanger to try out other ships for various play styles and have fun trying out different genres of music to play to different beats!

[b] My new arcade favorite [/b]

First of all I bought this game at the summer sale for 1,39€. I don't think I would buy it if I had to pay over 5€, but let's get into it.

The download took about two minutes, and I could enjoy the game right away. I picked up my Xbox 360 controller and sat down after I had a quick coffee. 

I was met with the most flashing and colourful startup screen ever, and even the menus were pretty intence. This game is not for people with epilepsy, so don't even try it if you think you have it. Now the menus and settings was pretty easy to navigate, as you would expect from an arcade shooter.

[b][u]The music[/u][/b]

The game came with a lot of music, but it clarely wasn't my taste, so you probably have to download some yourself. It can be hard if you don't have much technical knowledge though, as you have to browse your folders and find your music manually.

Anyways, I bought the Mega Bundle, so I could play m4a files from my iTunes folders. But you can actually just convert your iTunes music to the mp3 format to play them, so the DLC s pretty useless. I did miss a Soundcloud implementation though, it was pretty good in Audiosurf 2.

[b][u]The game[/u][/b]

So I selected 'Wake Me Up' by Avicii, and gave it a go. The start was very similar to the good old Atari game, Astroids. Big astroids came flying by and became smaller pieces upon destruction, as you would expect. But after some time, the game became something pretty different.

Lots of spaceships attacked my ship and performed the old art of kamikaze. Most ships doesn't shoot projectiles, but they try to destroy my ship in many different ways. Some ships gather around me and try to squash me, some try to pull me like a vacuum cleaner and there is even a ship that will try to choak me like a king cobra. So there is obviously a big variety of enemies.

The best part was probably how the game adopted to different songs. I could play almost any song I wanted and the gameplay would still be awesome.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[b][u]Pros and Cons[/u][/b]

[u]Pros:[/u]

Fun and addictive gameplay

Great variety of perks and powerups

Cool colours and graphic effects

Many levels, unlocks and achievements
 
Local and online cross-platform co op

No bugs/glitches (after my experience)

[u]Pros:[/u]

No Soundcloud implementation

Too fast to level up at the start

A little too pricey for an arcade shooter

Useless iTunes & m4a file support DLC
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[b][u]Overall rating: 9/10[/u][/b]

Never before have I played a game where I can actually shoot my music.  But seriously, this game is awesome!  It has full iTunes support (with the proper DLC), it runs at a silky smooth 60 FPS, and the replayabilty is off the charts if you have thousands of songs on your PC (or Mac!) like me.  If your music playlist is big enough, you will literally NEVER run out of levels in this game!  If only they made this portable so we could blast the heck our music on our iOS devices anywhere we go...OH, WAIT.  There is!  There's also an iOS version of this game that you can take anywhere and play the tracks on your iPod Touch or similar iOS device.  Granted, that version is a BIT scaled down, but it retains the fun and replayabilty of the PC/Mac version, more or less.  But the compatability is not even the best part...

This game has full controller support and works beautifully with an Xbox 360 controller.  In fact, this game is a twin-stick shooter, through and through.  So you SHOULD play it with a gamepad. x3  And the graphics, while a bit limited in terms of 2D sprites, are very vibrant and colorful thanks to all the pryotechnics and lights that actually sync up to your music!  Is it too bright?  Turn the intensity down!  Do you want more color and lights?  Then, turn the intensity up more!  

And not only do you get vivid graphics, great controls, and limitless replayabilty, but you also get a good handful of ships to unlock and play as.  And all of them play differently, each with their own varying styles of play.  In addition to the already substansial selection of playiable ships in the vanilla version, you can upgrade to the Ultra version and get more ships, more gameplay variety, more everything!  Not to mention that there is also the Shadow Ops DLC which adds even MORE ships and a new layer of gameplay!  But wait...did I mention this game has full Steam Workshop support as well?  Soooo...you get even MOOOORE ships to play as in addition to what the base game and DLCs give you!

I think I've said enough.  It goes without saying that every audiophile should have this in his or her Steam library.  If you don't, you are missing out on a totally innovative musical experience!

I am a huge fan of music and rhythm-based games. It comes as no surprise that I really love Beat Hazard.

Two things to take note of. Music-based games are always more fun if you are actually an avid lover and listener of music. The same is true for Beat Hazard. I love music and thus I love the ability to start up the game and try out a song that I really enjoy. This kind of individual customization within games like this gives it a high replay value.

Secondly, Beat Hazard is bright. And I don't mean smart. It's seriously bright and colourful, to the point where my eyes sometimes feel like that are taking some strain. It does look amazing, though. Me being a bit strange, I absolutely love it. It's like an audio-visual explosion, and it's phenomenal.

So what about the gameplay? I find it solid, fun and challenging, which really is what you want out of this type of game. It often starts off slow and easy, only to suddenly explode into a frenzy of dodging and explosions. The game keeps you entertained and you get to listen to great music (your own!).

Lastly, I want to point out that this game is good regardless of the music. Shooting on the rhythm of the beat and sound and having something great to listen to makes the game awesome, but what is great is that the game manages to play well and succeed at being fun even without that element. Essentially, it doesn't rely on the music for the game to be good. It is good, regardless. Some people may argue that games like AudioSurf rely too much on the music (although, I still absolutely love AudioSurf), and it is worth mentioning that it is not true for this game.

Even so, the music does make the game just that much more enjoyable. Along with fantastic, over-the-top visuals, fun gameplay and great replay value this game succeeds in what it sets out to do.

8/10 (if you are a music-lover).

Basically an interactive visualizer for your music. It's actually pretty easy when you get the hang of it (compared to other shooters I mean) but that isn't a bad thing. It's more of a casual game despite its intense visuals, and sometimes that's exactly what you need.

The only major downside IMO is that you can't turn off the effects. I like explosions and stuff but some of the effects are unnecessary, such as debris having strobe lights too, making it somewhat confusing especially at higher difficulties when you blast a lot of things at a time. If only pieces of an asteroid or broken ship didn't blink, the effects would've been perfectly fine with me.

Notes:
- The more complicated your song, the harder it gets really. So if you have songs that shift around between low and high intensity sections (progressive rock/metal, trance, many orchestral pieces, etc.), it tends to get harder because the power if your guns and the enemies slow down but continuously spawn, which allows them to build up. After that low intensity part if it suddenly gets a high intensity part, you'll likely be facing a lot of explosions.

- It doesn't like non-English song/file/folder names, but it'll read the file properly. It just displays as gibberish (ASCII) in-game. Minor issue but it makes it harder to find certain songs (unless you rename them, which I don't want to do) especially if most of your music is non-English. I have to wait for the song to play in preview to figure out what it is.


All in all a good time waster and eye strainer. If you were just gonna chill and listen to your music anyway, do it with this game instead so you get to sharpen your reflexes, eye-to-hand coordination and whatnot while you're at it.

I was hoping for something like AudioSurf only with an arcadey space shooter twist.

What I got, was far from what I was hoping, and it was very underwhelming.

First, I stumbled around trying to find music, it starts with music I guess from the games built in library or something?

So I went into options to find my own music, okay, i need to index it, and this was the first negative for the game.

When you have over 2,000 songs in your downloads folder, indexing songs like this over having it as a browsing thing like what Audiosurf does makes it take a very, very, very, very, very very long time for someone who has lots of music, I ended up getting tired of waiting for it to finishing indexing the music at around the 4,500 song mark, this is not even 10 percent or less of my library as I believe last count I had over 20,000 songs.

It also appeared, to find a song, you need to browse through them using the "N" key, which is ENTIRELY impractical for such a huge amount of songs.

Alright, so maybe the actual game will offer what I am hoping for, so I went to play one of Abigor's songs since it was a very fast song. I was hoping to see some very fast gameplay and colors and flashes all over the place.

HHAHAHA... Nope. You're basically just floating around in space with random objects spawning at you and shooting you, the song did not dictate how fast the gameplay was so it was basically just playing in the background.

Oh, and to make it worse, you need to pick up powerups for extra volume..

Very misleading if you ask me.

I do not recommend this game if you are looking for games similar to Audiosurf as this, is DEFINITELY, not it.

Beat hazard is a slightly unique twin stick shooter that reacts to your music!

Outside the music part this game is mainly an average twin stick shooter, however it is built around your music library. The faster the tempo and louder the song, the faster and more powerful everything is. Despite being somewhat repetitive there is much fun to be had if you like twin stick arcade shooters and jamming to your music. There is a leveling system that keeps the game somewhat fresh, allowing you to unlock more power up slots and different abilities.
There isn't much to say, this game is well built and will bring you hours of fun if you like arcade like games and listening to your music library.

Easy to add music

Reacts to music levels and tempo

Cons
Gets Repetitive

Considering my first 5 minute test run of this game turned into a 40 minute shoot fest, I have to admit this game is pretty downright addicting! 

Pros: 
-Simple Gameplay mechanics so it's quick to learn
-No longer having to decide between listening to music or playing games
-As both the enemies and your guns are affected by the music, there is always a very fluid balance
-As many levels as you have music
-Plenty of growth with bonuses, unlocks to keep you interested

Cons:
-VERY visually overpowering (I have it set to 50% and it's still pretty mind numbing so take the siezure warning seriously)
-3/4 time songs are a pain to do.... Death Waltz has new meaning!
-Any song that goes quiet for the bridge is DEADLY
-The money system is not quite intuitive.... I end up with less money than I collect over the level (this is probably me being dumb though)
-Not so much a con but it would be nice to be able to link youtube videos or music websites the same way we can do internet radio

Final thoughts:
This game is awesome! The level generation based on music is done beautifully making it difficult but never impossible. It is visually overwhelming but in the most beautiful way. Give it a try and I hope you find your 5 minute game sessions bursting into hour long adventures as well!

So I just bought this game, because I play a lot of rhythm games and Steam recommended it to me and it looked cool and it's on sale for $5 so I thought, "Why not?" This game is hell. Fun hell, but hell nontheless. It's part Galaga, part bullet hell, part rhythm game. And it is hard.

Galaga - You are a ship, in space, shooting at other ships, in space. The ships, look like they're from from Galaga. Nuff said.

Bullet hell - Unlike Galaga, where ships shoot in relatively straight lines, these ships shoot in all sorts of funky patterns.

Rhythm game - Lots of games are coming out that allow you to input your own music, and the game tailors to level to it. This game does not disappoint. The speed of the ships depends on the speed of the music, and the difficulty of the ships depends on the intensity of the song. So if you're gonna play some dubstep with this like I am well... good luck.

Do I recommend? Yes, yes I do. But IF YOU ARE PHOTOSENSITIVE DO NOT GET THIS GAME. Don't even watch the videos. I'm serious. This is murder on the eyes. You can even turn down the intensity of the graphics. It's still eye murder.

[quote=CynicalPopcorn]OH FOR F*** SAKE I DIED RIGHT AT THE END OF THE SONG F***... F*** this game. I love it.[/quote]

[i]CynicalPopcorn's HIGHLY Recommended! | 9.75/10[/i]
[i]Good value for money? [b]YES![/b][/i]

[i][b]WARNING:[/b]The game has a LOT of bright, flashing lights and as such people with photosensitivity issues should take this into consideration.[/i]

[h1]Beat Hazard Summary[/h1]
A twin stick shooter not only powered by music, but powered by YOUR music! Beat Hazard takes your songs and puts you into a world of intense, twin-stick shooter action. The music you play really impacts the flow of the game from the enemies that spawn to how fast and frantic movement on the screen is, especially when taking into account the wonderful, very bright visuals.

The game alone, "regular" Beat Hazard is awesome, however for the TRUE feel of the game purchasing the entire set of DLC is worth every penny. The "Ultra" DLC adds more ranks, new enemy, higher difficulty and improves the game all round. Then, to add to this chaos, the "Shadow Operations Unit" DLC adds a VERY nice element of challenge that adds a new ranking system along side the normal one which rewards the player for completing challenges. This, however, is not easy as a death during a challenge will set you back. Be it that the current song does not count towards a total of songs completed on 'x' difficulty, or that you lose ALL (yes, all) progress in that challenge, deaths are even more unbearable than usual.

Please note: In order to use songs from iTunes you will need to purchase the "iTunes & m4a file support" DLC. It's cheap, and I understand why they've done it. You're best off buying the mega bundle anyway as all the DLC is worth it.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Excellent top-down, twin-stick shooter powered by your music library!
[*]Good difficulty curve that gets VERY tough at high difficulties.
[*]Incredibly fun to play!
[*]Great replayability - Many different enemies, bosses, gamemodes and each song is unique.
[*]Co-op or Competetive multiplayer fun.
[*]Gamemodes are very interesting and well done!
[*]Custom made ships that are actually quite balanced!
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Flashing lights. Very bright flashing lights to be precise. A BIG WARNING to those who suffer from photosensitivity issues.
[/list]

[h1]Judgement[/h1]
Beat Hazard gets CynicalPopcorn's HIGHLY recommended judgement with a score of 9.75/10.

The game is extremely fun with very high replayability. Difficulty is fair and the visuals are lovely. All-round well made twin-stick shooter that should not be overlooked by those who enjoy similar games like Audiosurf (music aspect) and want to try it with a bullet-hell twist.

Also, yes that is a genuine quote. This game and I have an unstable relationship of me mostly yelling cause I play poorly followed by myself immediately crawling right back to it.

Beat Hazard combines the basic gameplay elements of the old classic arcade game Asteroids and mixes it with different kind of enemy types and your own choice of music. Every song has different kind of enemy waves so each song feels a completely unique experience and doesn't get boring after a song or two. Because the game is just pure arcade action the game never really lose any of it's replayability and feels fresh every time you launch up a new song in Beat Hazard.

Consider picking up the DLCs! Enchants the gameplay and adds hours of content into the game.

I have played Audiosurf for a long time and I was not sure if Beat Hazard was a game that could stand out for me as a music-based game. I finally decided to give Beat Hazard a try after it was available for several years on the market. It feels like a game inspired by the classic game Asteroids, but with songs from your music library playing while you control your spaceship. So the basic premise of the game is you maneuvering a spaceship while avoiding asteroids and many enemy spaceships of varying types and sizes. There are many games of this genre in a crowded market, but Beat Hazard carves out its own identity with its challenging action and allows you to take on numerous enemies and other hazards as you enjoy the rhythm of the songs of your favorite artists and built-in songs.

There had been criticism of Beat Hazard because of the lack of iTunes support. I strongly recommend buying the related Beat Hazard DLC that supports iTunes songs. I played songs from iTunes and they work just fine. The game accepts all song file types with the exception of CDs, so you will have to rip the CDs in order to play the songs. Another criticism had been that Beat Hazard doesn’t seem exciting enough on slow songs. I played many slow songs, including some pop/soft rock songs, and there is enough intensity in the visuals and the mayhem to make the gameplay exciting. It is beautiful to see your spaceship’s bright neon fire fill the screen while the explosions are so vibrant. There are times when the brightness of the visuals is a bit overdone, especially as the track progresses. When the visuals are too intense it can feel uncomfortable for those with sensitive eyes. Therefore, it would be best to take a break from the action if the flashing strobe feels overwhelming.

There are several gameplay modes in the game and many spaceships to choose from. The standard mode requires you to play through an entire track until it is finished. Survival mode requires you to last as long as possible while trying to play through an entire album. The spaceships have their own specific missions such as accumulating a minimum number of points without getting the death penalty that would nullify some or all of the points you had scored previously. These specific missions for spaceships add to the challenge of playing this old-school shooter while enjoying the rhythm of whatever song you are playing. There is a boss rush mode that requires you to defeat wave after wave of bosses until you have no more lives remaining. The bosses become familiar after experiencing the standard modes since bosses appear at specific points of the song. These modes are exciting in their own way, but it feels like there aren’t too many other modes to further increase replay value. However, there is online play that allows you to play the various modes with a friend. The bottom of the screen adds a nice touch to the game by notifying you of your progress, your friends’ progress, and other players who are looking to playing with others.

You can level up in the game and that happens as you progress through each track. After leveling up enough you will earn a new rank and you can see how you rank against other players on the global leaderboard. There is no leaderboard for individual songs like Audiosurf, but Beat Hazard’s way of leveling up provides a sense of progression. I played with the mouse and keyboard setup and it plays quite well. There is the option of playing with a controller.

There are many powerups in the game. As you pick up volume and power powerups, your spaceship’s lasers become increasingly powerful, but the gameplay will also intensify. The screen fills up with a large number of small enemy spaceships and large spaceships to balance the gameplay and keep you from being significantly overpowered.

I think Beat Hazard is a fun game that some players may find old after playing through their favorite tracks in all the available modes. However, this game is definitely worth the $9.99 purchase price plus the DLCs. You can’t go wrong with game that offers enough replay value that is as large as your music collection, vibrant visuals, intense boss battles, and lots of powerups.

What makes Beat Hazard addictive is the sheerly high amount of upgrades, weapons, and ships. The upgrades allow 3 items/weapons to be used, and ships are basically infinite because of the Steam Workshop. What makes the ship component special is the fact that every ship plays in a different way, making the gameplay a total conversion.
I'm not saying that Audiosurf/Audiosurf 2 is inferior to Beat Hazard, I'm just saying that I personally prefer Beat Hazard because of it variative fast-paced gameplay and modes.

In today's modern gaming scene, I can't help but get the feeling that games aren't doing enough to engage the player. Sure, you can toss "realistic"-behaving grenades at other players in Call of Duty, or build cool things in Minecraft, or what-have-you. However, I just get the feeling that the sense of fun, the sense of joy in games just isn't there any more. Games just don't engage players so much. They don't captivate you as much as they could.

Beat Hazard is a game that takes that feeling and punches it in the nose, and doesn't stop punching until your mind is rainbows and flashing strobe lights.

LSD is included, too. Just crank those visual fx up to 200% and play in a darkened room late at night at suicidal difficulty. You're welcome.

It's been on my wishlist for a while and it was gifted to me recently - and unfortunately it's a lot less fun than I'd imagined it to be! I'm biased for these kinds of games since I like challenging arcade games and music-powered games, so you'd think I'd like this one. Yes, well... not really.

(Mind you, I'm in no way photosensitive like some others who have left a negative review on this game have been, and I can handle rapid flashing just fine, but if it becomes gameplay-inhibiting, then the design is absolutely flawed.)

Problems with the game:
* Often screen-filling visual effects that prevent you from seeing what is going on. You can't dodge bullets if you can't see them...
* Overboard on the "flashy sparkly fireworks" effects. I mean, way overboard, and then some. It's not "cool", it's not "attractive", and it gives you a headache if you're not careful.
* The music plays very soft. I have properly balanced music files and they simply don't play at a decent volume in the game - for a music-focused game you'd expect the audio component to be at least adequate and give priority to proper playback without having to amplify it into clipping ranges.
* Scoring is meaningless: levels are random, so what rewards you get and points you score for a song is not dependent on the music at all. Score is determined by chance and not by skill, as a result.
* Music-based firepower will favor even, loud songs. You get a dynamic song with breaks and softer parts and you're pretty much at the mercy of whatever random fleets of ships are thrown your way with no way to fight them off. And woe if you hit a quiet spot when a boss is thrown at you. Good luck with that, get ready for a grind.
* Screen-filling visual effects that.. Ohwait, I already said that. :P Yes, it's a problem. Worthy of mentioning twice. It kills the ability to properly play a "bullet hell" game. Period.
Crap. Don't buy it.

This game has about a dozen serious flaws and countless minor ones. Being completely blasted by neon rainbows any time you do just about anything will probably make you want to rip your eyes out halfway through your first song. Even if it doesn't, there's basically no way to see any important information on the screen, like small ships and hazardous debris. More than half the time I die, it's not because I failed to dodge a bullet or enemy, but is instead because of something that I never saw at all.
Power-ups will appear for a short duration, but the warning that they are about to disappear might as well not have been bothered being added given it's lack of usefulness. By the time they start to blink, unless you're practically on top of them already, there is no way you could possibly make it to pick them up anyways. This happens extremely frequently given that they drop randomly from enemies, and the enemies will frequently appear in extremely long strings from off screen. As a result, the enemies you kill will drop power-ups you can't reach because they are obstructed by other enemies.
The stream of enemies from off screen is also frustrating, as like many top-down shooters in a box, enemies can appear from off screen right where you are without warning. As a result, you are really restricted to an even smaller play area unless you'd like to risk rage and frustration.
Song volume seems to be a cosmetic power-up with no tangible effect in game. Added to the lack of significant differences between enemy appearance (there are about 5 non-bosses, with 3 beings practically identical), the game feels like it suffers from a shocking shortage of creativity. 
All in all, I highly recommend you avoid buying this game. Despite liking this style of game (both top-down arcade shooters and dynamic music driven games) I feel like I wasted my money even though I picked it up for just a few dollars during a sale.

I've long been searching for a rhythm game with more entertaining gameplay than audiosurf's mono mode, but that requires less focus than Audiosurf's other modes,  so that I can enjoy the music. Beat Hazard claims to provide a 2D shooter that uses the music to generate the enemies, their movement, and your attack power; and were this the case it would be exactly what I was looking for.

However the music element of this game is simply tacked onto a fairly generic 2D space shooter. The enemy spawning appears to have more to do with the amount of time you are into the level, and if the music has any affect on it, I have not noticed it. The only effect music appears to actively have on the gameplay is the speed of enemy craft, and the speed (and colourfulness) of your guns. The only other way that the music interacts with the game, are volume power-ups, which you pick up to increase the volume of the music – and that brings me to my next big complaint: The game doesn't let you enjoy the music. The music starts of almost inaudible, and only reaches acceptable volumes after 3-5 volume power-ups (which you will loose when destroyed.) Even then, the sounds of your guns, and the other craft exploding will completely drown out the music – whoever came up with the volume feature clearly didn't understand the appeal of music games.

The visual design also has its issues. The gun and explosion effects are bright and garish, filling large portions of the screen and yet don't synch with the music at all. This would be a fine design for a bullet hell game (although still heavily entrenched at the garish end of them), but the way it is executed detracts heavily from the musical aspects of the game; this is particularly true when the genre of music is more relaxed and serene. The truth is that the game as a whole does a very bad job of conveying the feel of the tracks used, caring only for the music's volume to determine enemy and bullet speeds. Say what you like about Audiosurf, but at least that game made the tracks you surfed on feel like the song that was playing – and didn't get in the way of you listening to them.

I would not recommend this game, there are better examples of the two genres it is trying the fuse, and a superior version of this game can be achieved by finding a good 2D space shooter, turning the music off, and playing your own in the background. I suppose my search for a better rhythm game continues.

I like to call Beat Hazard "Lens Flare, The Game". It's the epileptic's worst nightmare. It's also faaaaaantastic.

It's only peripherally a music game. Regardless, it's an exceptional one-screen shoot-em-up in the vain of Asteroids that succeeds without relying on the musical gimmick.

The shooting is loads of fun. You blast a pretty decent variety of ships and bosses into clouds of metallic debris. It's extremely satisfying picking huge enemies to pieces. In the true "bullet hell" style you must dodge projectiles and kamikaze enemies while navigating the playfield and picking up powerups.

It's a very good game in every respect, and the programmer is active in development and in conversation on the forums. The addition of Steam Workshop sweetens the pot even further. Beat Hazard is very well worth your money and time as long as you're not really looking for a "music game".

This game is equal parts Geometry Wars, Guitar Hero, and visualization software. Similar to Asteroids, the perspective is top-down, and you have free reign to move your ship in any direction (however, you are limited by the borders of the screen). The ideal way to play this game is with an Xbox 360 controller, as it is a twin-stick shooter (similar to Smash TV).

The major selling point is that it is also a visualizer. So, your "stages" are actually music tracks. The game ships with several dance/house/edm tracks, however you can add to that listing with music saved onto your hard drive, and for $1.00, you can add iTunes and m&a support. Because it's a visualizer, everything pulsates with the beat of the music; shots, powerups, and your ships lights all thump with the beat. Because of this, certain genres resonate better with it than others (club/hip hop/dance/edm/dubstep/soul/funk/pop being the best, with metal/psychobilly/punk being the most spasmatic). Interestingly, the game will sync enemies and bosses with the music, so when a song gets to a really intense part, you may suddenly get hit with twin bosses and similarly when there's not much going on in the track, you may wind up staring at an empty screen. The game also takes more detail into the game from your music selection by making adjustments to things like enemy/bullet speed, how many of your guns fire during the quieter segments, and how fast time-based score multiplier meters fill up.

The ideal purchase to make for this game is the Mega Bundle Pack, as it contains all of the DLC (including the aforementioned iTunes/m&a licensing). These include online co-op/competitive play, new bosses, and perks that can be applied to your gameplay, and the Shadow Ops Unit DLC, which adds a rank progression system, ship-specific goals (like destroy 100 asteroids, reach 1,000,000 points in a track), leaderboards for each ship, and even opens up the ship creating system to you. The higher you rank in the Shadow Ops Unit, the more points you get in creating a ship. It also lets you select an image on your hard drive for the ship and upload your creation to the steam workshop for others to download and use. This also means that you can download ships that other users have created (I've seen quite a few Millennium Falcons, Starship Enterprises, X-Wing Fighters, and Tie Fighters, but have also seen the Planet Express Ship, ships from other shooters, and even the Tardis).

However, due to the nature of this game's fast moving, brightly colored flashing particle effects, this is not something for epileptics to play or be around, as it will made them seize faster than Axl Rose would find a reason to not play a show. For the rest of us, the $16.99 price point for the Mega Bundle pack is really cheap. While there's virtually no story, it is quite fun to see what the game makes of your favorite music as well as push for the oldschool arcade goals of getting a high score.

Beat Hazard is a game that lies along the same vein as Audiosurf, only instead of a racing game its a space shooter (think Asteroids, that really old game with the triangle ship).  You can use the music you have on your computer to power the battlefield as you blast away your foes.  It's a simple, but addicting game, especially with the DLC that adds the Shadow Missions (objectives for you to complete with different ships).  The gameplay is simple: you shoot the living crap out of anything that moves on-screen while trying not to get exploded.

The only major issue I have with this game is that the visuals are sometimes too distracting.  I usually turn the visual intensity option down to 50% when I play, because otherwise it actually kinda hurts my eyes.  This also makes it hard to see some of the projectiles coming towards you, resulting in some really cheap deaths where you literally couldn't see what blew you up.  Since you basically die in one hit, it can be a pain, especially if you're trying to complete a Shadow Mission.

Other than that it's a load of fun to hop in and blow up enemies while listening to your favorite music.  It's well worth the bundle that includes all the DLC as well if it goes on sale.  Buying it full price really depends on how much fun you think you'll have with it.  It's definitely more hardcore than the likes of Audiosurf.  If that's your thing, then put your money down and get shooting.

A pure blast. Played it on Ps3 then on PC and it was a real pleasure both times. Now with the new DLC it adds more "challenge" (not that hard, but I count on the workshop to fix that). Compared to other musical games such as symphony or audiosurf, the level is way higher. I highly recomend it.

I love this game. It's just the right amount of simplicity and depth... It's a basic concept, take your music, have the music generate levels that dynamically react to that music and power your weapons in kind... This basic idea has then been continously refined and improved upon until you have a really well developed fun little game to get your adreniline pumping while listening you your favourite tunes and enjoying some eyecandy.

Just a heads up before we go any further, this is a very visually intense game... If you are photo sensitive this game is not for you... While it is possible the low visuals setting and monitor calibration might make the game playable for you, I wouldn't risk it. It's a great game but it is intensionally designed to explosion of flashing coloured lights... And while delightful it's not worth risking your health... For everyone else... The higher the visual intensity the higher your high score, so blow you eyes out. :-P

As you can see from the screenshots the visuals are a major selling point for the game. Remember those old console demo disks and media player plug ins we used to download so we could have pretty procedural visulaisers  for our music? Well this game provides that, dials it up to 11 and then includes a damn decent if simple SHMUP as well.

I've followed it since launch and it started out just simple and enjoyable. However, the developer was highly active here on the steam forums and receptive to feedback to fine tune the game and continued to develop it the right way... That is to take in that feedback and come up with their own inovative solutions to the shortcommings. For example when the community demanded the addition of powerups the developer opted to rather than shoehorn in the standard cliché powerups seen in every shmup, to creatively create some inovative unique powerups of their own, their own system for collecting and using them and tailored existing and new enemies specifically to them to make a more dynamic interesting play experience.

The developer even went so far as to fix problems by adding new features we didn't even no we needed, but now we have them we couldn't live without them... I highly recommend getting the full package. The DLC for this game came much later but rounded out the play experience more then I could have imagined. With the core game, ultra and the shadow missions DLC you'll have a great balanced progression through the ranks as you upgrade you ship and refine your skills so you will simentaniously hit your peak in all departments right as you reach the top of the rankings, fully unlocking all the customisable  features so you having mastered the game you can fully adjust everything to suit your play style before you shift to targeting the leader boards and competing with your friends.

At time of writing I have every achievment (some easy, some hard), unlocked every feature and have invested a solid amount of time playing and mastering all the different game modes and features... And I'm not done. As I find new gems and get new songs to add to my media library I shall return to play them out repeatedly in beat hazard to the pleasure of my eyes and reflexes as well as my ears. I wouldn't spend all day playing it (now that I've completed the progression to obtain all unlockables), but it is a game I happily come back to for a few hours again and again every other week for a bit of fun and challange... Not to mention dive in to compete with my friends with from time to time. I recommend it to pretty much everyone (except the photosensitive).

This is a pretty fun game, definitely get the bundle for the full experience.  Wait till you master the game before you try the shadow missions though. Online games arent very populated so you might have to host a public game often and wait patiently for someone to challenge.  Don't expect a plot, just sit back and enjoy your own personal disco in space.

At its core, Beat Hazard is a very simple game. It's just a twin-stick shooter where you shoot at asteroids and enemies while trying to avoid touching them. The game's main advertising point is that the aesthetics and enemy generation of the game are based around the music you play, where each “stage” is a song. For example, if you’re at a loud part of the song, the game will throw a bunch of enemies at you but also increase your firepower. As a singleplayer game, it’s neat to say the least. However, I recommend Beat Hazard as a multiplayer game with a friend. That way, you get that weird joy of listening to a song with your friend while also trying to not burn through all of your shared lives. It can be rather fun chaos in the game, and my friends and I would have several systems on who got to pick the next song.
There are a few janky aspects of Beat Hazard to make that dream happen, though. First, you need both you and your friends to the same exact song files into Beat Hazard…and if you have a ton of songs, it’s a rather lengthy process where the game demands to be open. Plus, the songs are all presented in one list with limited sorting options, so if you’re looking for a specific song and you have a lot, you have to hope to not scroll past it. Furthermore, only one person can control the menus, so if your friend is the host and tends to be uncooperative, that could be an issue. 
The game’s not perfect, but I think if the idea of playing multiplayer Asteroids with a friend based around songs you pick sounds like fun, it’s worth a pickup, probably on sale.

Beat Hazard is one of THOSE games.

Those games that, for whatever reason, you simply feel the urge to play at random times.

Those games in which you have an absolute blast but for some reason just can't play for an extended period of time.

I bought Beat Hazard on XBLA at launch and logged probably 100 hours or more, fast-forward several years and my music tastes have changed, and so has my taste in video games. Back when I was a teen, when Beat Hazard first came out, I listened almost exclusively to metal and played pretty much nothing but shooters; now I listen to rap and EDM and get giddy at the thought of playing an RPG; how has this affected my thoughts of this game? Absolutely none.

Beat Hazard is a game in which you blow shit up and listen to your favorite jams, these tunes procedurally generate the enemy spawns, types, speed, bosses and even the damage of your own gun. If you're a fan of music then you'll probably like this game, if you like bullet-hell games then you'll LOVE this game, if you are prone to epileptic attacks then you should NOT, under ANY CIRCUMSTANCES play this game.


Ask me 7 years ago what I'd rate Beat Hazard and I'd say 8/10, ask me today and I'll say the same thing.

Probably the most addicting game on Earth if you're an audiophile. Well worth the purchase if you have a decent music library built up.

SEIZURE WARNING: Even if you think that's funny for whatever reason, I can assure you this game is incredibly disorienting and hard to play for long periods of time.

It's a great game to jam out to with fun mechanics, powereups, and co-op.

but PLEASE use the game settings to turn down the intensity to the lowest level possible first. I'm not joking. See for yourself and turn it up if you can handle it but do not just play on the default level of effects. I can compare this game to playing a staring contest with a Disney fireworks display, only they all explode simultaneously and at eye level.

WARNING: Seizure-inducing visuals. Especially if you're a point-monger and turn the visual effects up to 200% for the bonus it gives you.

That being said, this is a lovely, simple, "I'm going to spend the next few hours blowing s*** up" game. Games like this usually see me muting the ingame music and playing my own list of songs, but rejoice! The level selection is actually a file system where you can pick your music! Remember that [..] means "go back," because they threw in a hint of DOS syntax.

The influence the song has on the gameplay is, as some negative reviews mention, pretty low. This is not a rhythm game where the beats of the music are literally what you should be pressing. Instead, the intensity of the music correlates to how fast projectiles move, how fast enemies move, and how much laser you shoot. Calm sections give you a chance to breathe, while intense sections turn the screen white and make your eye doctor cry.

There's some depth to it with the perks, upgrades, and DLC missions involving different player ships with different properties. I also enjoy the leaderboards, as low on them as I am. Adds some reason for a competitive player to stick around with the game and try to max out their scores as much as possible.

It really is a fun, small game though, and I recommend it if you want to blast your own music while shooting things with an obscene light show of lasers.

Beat Hazard

Beat Hazard is a twin-stick shooter game powered by the tempo and bass of your music, each track gives a different challenge and treats you with a pretty light show.

Pros

* Addictive gameplay

* Workshop support

* Challenging gameplay

* Great when killing time

* You can control the visual intensity, meaning if you're epileptic or prone to seizures you can still play

Cons

* Requires constant self updating because you gotta add your own tracks

In short, Beat Hazard will be the best 10 bucks you might spend on steam, it's an arcade style twin-stick shooter with a twist and perfect for music enthusiast, I'd pick this game up and give it a go if I were you, and remember if you don't like it you can always refund it, to those who start playing. May the Bass be with you.

After playing like 4 hours of this [b]BULLSHIT[/b], I a humble gamer, also another blinded(literally) person, wanted to write a review! So, "What is Beat Hazard?". 

Beat Hazard is an action/arcade game where you need to blow up shit-tons of enemy spaceships while maintaining your tiny ass ships "one-hit KO" HP. Sounds fun right? ...Right?

OK. It might not be appealing at first sight but once you buy(or get) it and boot up the game, you'll find that you are going to need to move all your music to an easily accessible place. Because Beat Hazards file browser SUCKS! I kid you not, it really does. But worry not my friend who still has his/her eyesight, because once you get the hang of it, you will easily pick the song you want and start sending those spaceships to space junkyard, I guess.

Alright, we booted up the game. Closed the game. Moved every piece of music we have in our PC to a better place. Opened up the game again. Picked the song. Now what? Now it's the time to have fun! Simply click anywhere to shoot while using WASD(Honestly I don't remember if I changed the key bindings so go check your settings before hopping into the game.) to move around. You might find that the power of your weapons, as well as the speed of the game, is dependent on the music that is currently playing. Ehem... [h1][b]BEAT[/b] Hazard[/h1]

While playing the game you will die a lot, but don't rage you'll learn to dodge while slowly turning your loyal eyeballs into fried cheeseballs. No one said there is no price but if you really want to see for 2 more days go ahead and turn down the intensity of effects. Actually turn down the intensity because when you max it out(200% is the max value) like I did. You can't see shit, there will be literally too much bullshit on your screen. Enemies, FAKIN ASTEROIDS, You and last but not least bullets(or Danmaku 弾幕 if you prefer the original usage or you are a weeaboo like me). 

Let us start with the enemies, there are 6 type of enemies listed by their difficulty to take down;

•Small grey ships, their duty is being as annoying as they can be while trying to flank and kamikaze you.

•Medium sized red decalled white ships, their duty is sometimes shooting and sometimes trying to kamikaze you.

•Big blue ships, their duty is shooting Homing Yellow Danmaku which can be destroyed if shot upon.

•Armada(that's what I call them), their duty is coming in sizes of 20+ and cover the whole screen while shooting at you at once from all sides.

•Boss, not much to say simple boss just shoot its weak points.

•Twin Boss, little brothers of the Boss.

About the asteroids in the game, what they are known for is getting in your way of having fun. Whether they spawn in the middle of the most [i]epicest[/i] guitar solo of all times or bump into your ship in the most unsuspecting time. You won't expect it because you are going to be dealing with 513 enemies at once. [spoiler]FUCK ASTEROIDS[/spoiler]

Now let's talk about how the game uses your music to spawn enemies. Based on my observations the bassier the sound is the more action you'll get. I think the best example would be Orion from Metallica. There is a bass passage in the beginning of the song. This makes the game think "IT'S SHOWTIME BABY" and you'll end up getting your face melted before the song even started. Orion is the hardest song I have ever played in this game. Considering the piece is 8 minutes long with almost 4 minutes of bass solo. This means 4 minutes of non-stop action. [spoiler]My biggest disappointment was the system [b][i]almost[/i][/b] only takes bass as a measure. I personally enjoy listening to Power Metal, a genre which doesn't prioritise bass over treble. That's what you'll get FAKIN ASTEROIDS IN YOUR FAKIN GUITAR SOLO[/spoiler]


The game is overall great and fun to play with lots of replayability. You can basically play until you run out of music if that's ever going to happen. The downside is you need to be relaxed and very careful like you are going to beat the world record of being careful to spot every [strike]little annoying pieces of fucks[/strike] Small grey ships and all the Danmaku while there is literally shitstorm happening in your poor screen. I rate this game 8/10 but this doesn't mean it's bad. This game is super cool and fun. Go grab it!

Amazing Idea and an amazing execution as well. The game itself has a really high challenge level and many unlockables, this results in hours of entertainment and fun. If you buy the dlcs, you'll have acess to the Steam Workshop, which is provides thousands of downloadable ships, all of them with a unique handling and firing pattern/power, as well as a not-so-easy Shadow Mission.
Having a friend to play with you, doubles the fun as usual, the difficult escalates when playing coop (I did not tried the versus mode yet) making your ships balanced, not overpowered.
You can put basically any music/audio in your HD to work with the game, or make use of the radios provided by the game, that covers pretty much all genres of music you can think of.
_____________________________________________
 Now to some problems; - The quantity of visual effects on the screen can seriously f*ck up your eyes, you can turn down by a setting right before a level starts (Down to 50%, up to 200%) even though, stills massive when played in higher difficulties (Insane/Suicidal)
And when playing multiplayer, some desync may happen, causing your coop partner to suddenly freeze and afterwards, teleport randomly. Not a frequent issue.

There's a good chance you've already played a game like Beat Hazard. The concept is simple, a little ship that floats around the screen spewing forth several different types of bright, flashy laser blasts as fleets of ships of varying sizes try to bring you down. Countless games have used this ever-popular formula, but Beat Hazard stands out because its gameplay molds itself to the rhythm of the music tracks you import. While it's fun, frenzied, and flashy! I will admit that after an hour, the concept got a little stale for me. Either way, Beat Hazard is an entertaining diversion and a cool way to experience your music library.

TL;DR - You listen to your music, the game has actually ignores the beat most of the time, feels like it was made by a hyper child in Game-Maker 

I can see now why this game has no trailer. This is, without a doubt, the worst "play your own music!" game I've ever had the displeasure of trying. I don't think I could actually imagine a worse music based game, which is why I find myself reeling at the fact it has so many positive reviews.

For starts, the biggest thing is that this game probably functions about 30% around your music, that's it. For a game supposedly based around the songs you pick, it has almost no relation at all towards them. The only real thing that ties in to it are enemy spawns and your bullets. When the beat slows, so does your rate of fire. W o w. 

So what makes this game so awful? I love bright lights, they're catchy and hold your attention. This? I don't even have epilepsy and I think I had a small seizure. The music can be at the lowest point with the slowest beat, and the screen will still be flashing like you were watching the video feed of a camera thrown at a rave. It doesn't fit in the slightest. You can be listening to the fastest part of a song where enemies are everywhere, but the screen will just be black and softly flash white. Suddenly out of nowhere at all, the screen will just explode into a cancerous color-fest that will make you regret having your monitor on at all. I have no issues with things like this is they have a purpose. There is. No. Purpose. It doesn't fit the beat. It doesn't fit ANYTHING! It's just THERE. For no reason other than "wOw tHIs is rEAL coOL! FlaSHiNG lIGHts ArE GreaT For thE KIds?! yEAH!" 

This game truly feels like a free game you'd find on the Xbox Aracade for free, except this game is 10 dollars and makes you pay money to use a pretty common file type. That alone should get this game a negative review from people, but seemingly not. Everything in this game screams "This is my third Game-Maker creation and I have no idea what I'm doing!" It feels like it's made by a really hyper child who thinks that spastic lighting and "hardcore" menu transitions are the way of the future. 

People keep asking how such awful games keep making it on Steam, but then I see things like this getting 4k Overwhelmingly positive reviews and I have my answer.

Going through my entire steam library and writing reviews.

How to enjoy Beat Hazard:

Step 1: Download a minimum of 500 EDM tracks (any sub-genre, I've found that drum & bass and bassline work the best)
Step 2: Put your volume all the way up to 100%.
Step 3: Maximise the graphical settings.
Step 4: Put your menu visuals up to 200%.
Step 5: Put your in-game visuals up to 200%.
Step 6: Unlock "Suicidual" difficulty as soon as you can. ONLY PLAY IN THIS DIFFICULTY.
Step 7: Choose a 5min+ track with hard bass and drops.
Step 8: Turn all surrounding light sources. Make the room completely pitch-black.
Step 9: Have an epileptic fit & go blind.
Step 10: Sue Cold Beam Games - even though the first thing you see when you open up Beat Hazard is a disclaimer.
Step 11: After reading Step 10, decide to file a lawsuit anyway.
Step 12: Lose the lawsuit.
Step 13: Learn how to train your other senses apart from your sight - just like Daredevil.
Step 14: Go home.
Step 15: Play more Beat Hazard while blind, it's more challenging.

By the way, this is a good game.

I've had Beat Hazard in my library for years.  I love twin stick shooters and I love listening to music so it seems like a natural pairing.  The game is fun initially and does seem to sync to music, particulary more uptempo or aggressive songs that have a building to a peak structure about them.  Slower songs, jazz, classical and the like don't really work that well.  The game has built in support for several internet radio stations playing more obscure tracks which is nice, although tbh I usually play with my own tracks.

You'll unlock powerups and boosters as you go, and once you get a few it's easy to really rack up your scores.  The game is not all that challenging though.  Within a couple of hours I had unlocked everything, and tbh I'm not even that great at these kind of shooters. It's also very repetious, you'll see the same kind of enemies in the same sequence with mostly the same bosses regardless of what music you're playing.   It gets old after awhile.

Ultimately I quit playing so much as I moved to subscription based music services like Spotify and Google Play Music.  The game doesn't support these.  Since I rarely buy or download music any more I'm left with my old library to play on it.  Half the reason I liked the game was that it gave me something to do with my hands while I delved into new music, since it doesn't support the platforms I now use it's kind of fell by the wayside in the last few years.  

If you like twin stick shooters there are way better options out there.  If you like listening to new music while playing a game, and  you buy genuine music files it's worth ten bucks.  But don't expect much of a challenge or much variety, and be forewarned that if your not listening to upbeat pop, electronic or hard rock/metal it likely won't be that great of an experience.  I'm going to say not recommended because the audience that would like it and can play it seems small.  But if you fit the above niche go for it.

A classic arcade-style shooter.  It works like Asteroids, except your music IS the game.  The length of a song is the length of a level.  The faster the beat, the faster enemies come at you.  Want to relax and slowly shoot things?  Put on some Barry Manilow or Celine Dion.  Want a serious challenge?  Put on some Dragonforce or nightcore.  Maybe see if you can make it through "Stairway to Heaven."  This game literally has as many different levels as you have songs on your PC--and I know there are folks out there who, like me, have THOUSANDS of songs taking up dozens of GB of space.


The only downside is that this game, like many others, is NOT suited to the little touchpad-mouse that comes with a laptop--so if you don't already have a regular mouse, you'll have to buy one.  But come on, who tries to play a game like this with a laptop's crappy mouse anyway?

If you don't have this one in your library, BUY IT.  It's hundreds of hours of fun.
