Most of what's been said of the game doesn't need repeating - check just about any negative review and it'll tell you that the game is repetitive. Yes, it is. Unless you plan on buying the DLC (which I haven't), you'll play as the same ship fighting the same enemies across the same two (three if you count Chill Out) gamemodes. Which begs the question: Why do I still recommend it?

This game is not for lovers of the shoot 'em up genre. It's for people who love their music - people who can lose themselves through the majesty of the shuffle function and not need much stimulation to complement it. It's not next-level stuff. It's not going to blow your mind with what it does differently from its peers. Its experience doesn't come from the gameplay alone - Just check the first sentence of its description!

Beat Hazard, while not having as much content as one may like for a game of its caliber, doesn't cut corners. The visuals are very nice (even at 50%, which is the only way I can play), the ship handles well, hit detection performs as it should, and all in all, I have not encountered any glitches throughout my playtime. While I certainly would have liked more ships, bosses, power-ups, perks, and gamemodes (all of which are boasted in the DLC, which, again, I did not purchase), the amount I paid seems to fit the bill, and I'd personally prefer a smaller selection rather than an oversaturation of needless content. (Come on, who wants to bother memorizing boss attack patterns in a music game?)

There are certainly better games out there - better shoot 'em ups, better music games, what have you - but Beat Hazard should be treated as something meant to enhance your musical experience rather than as a standalone game. If you want to get lost in the game, certainly try something else more suited to your tastes. But if you're ready to get lost in your own music library again, don't rule it out just yet.

(This game was purchased on sale, and I have not purchased the DLC expansion. Given the amount of content there is, I would recommend that others do the same!)

Beat Hazard is an adequate twin stick shooter whose biggest strenght is the music integration. It offers up an engaging way to listen to your own tunes.

This game does have many flaws in my opinion. The blurb advertises a "unique ebb and flow based on the music". While this is technically true, even if it's unique it still feels all samey. No matter what song you're listening to, it's all the same basic experience. Sometimes, its dedication to going with the music works against it. This game is definitely more optomized for certain song structures and that makes playing through slower, quieter songs a slog. I could technically play through any song, but once I got to songs like FourFiveSeconds or Big Iron, the game kinda drudged along at an intensely slow pace.

Sometimes, the intensity of the game feels off with the music. As mentioned before, Beat Hazard really shines with a certain structure of song, most easily replicated by dubstep or any song that has a big drop as that is when the game can fluently change the intensity of the battle. However, sometimes it felt really off. Several times, when I was listening to quieter sections of songs, a big boss-like enemy comes to fight despite the calmer music and mood. At other times, when the beat drops in an electronic song, enemies are nowhere to be seen and it's just me and my super intense lasers versus some slow floating rocks.

My biggest complaint about the game, that might just be a me thing, is the visuals. When you boot up the game it warns about its use of strobing and a possibility of seizures. Now I haven't gotten a seizure from this game (yet), but the intensity of the visuals makes a drag to play for extended periods of time. Every time I've stopped playing, I've had a minor headache (nothing really serious just needed to step away from the computer for some time). 

Despite all these complaints, Beat Hazard really is the best way to play a twin stick shooter on steam simply for the music integration and I would still recommend it if your looking for a way to chill out (despite the intensity of the game) and listen to some toons.

TL;DR - Beat Hazard is the ideal twin-stick shooter for its music integration despite not perfectly working with the music and its overly-involved, bright, strobing visual style.

Beat Hazard is a fantastic little music game that takes music files you have and creates a twin-sticks shooter out of them.
The base Beat Hazard game contains three mode: Normal play, Survival, and Chill Out. Normal play has you selecting a single song, acting as one stage; this includes five different difficulties of play. You have until the end of the song to survive and score as many points as possible. Survival takes a list of your songs and plays them all in succession, the aim being to survive as long as possible while scoring points, ending when you have no lives left. Chill Out mode allows you to casually play along to songs without limited lives, enjoying the game without stress. Chill Out mode also employs the difficulty options of normal play. On top of all of this is an addictive little rank progression system.
With the addition of the Ultra DLC, however, this game becomes a completely different beast. New enemies, new weapons, the addition of perks and an upgrade system, and new multiplayer and Boss Rush modes all amount to being well worth the $5. There are also some smaller changes as well, such as your ship no longer moving with momentum à la Asteroids, which makes the game much more playable, and seemingly some changes to hitboxes.
All in all, I certainly recommend buying the base game, and cannot recommend buying the Ultra DLC along with it. Note that there is seperate DLC for the support of iTunes files, as well. I would also highly recommend a controller.

Edit: I'm back years later, with tons of new music. It's amazing to see a game grow so much without any input from the developer needed. Now I have hours and hours of new content to go through!

This game is a Bullet-Hell, plain and simple, but unique in the aspect of Music being the determining factor of how fast your game will go. Mixed with the Seizure-Inducing Visuals (warning btw) that can be boosted all the way to 200%, this game is made to be more for the Rock/Techno fans. 

You Control a Ship and play through songs pre-installed in the game's Album. As stated before, the Music is the Determining Factor on how fast the game will go and stop, as the music used will also Determine the Length of the level you need to survive in, if it's the Standard Mode. The Music controls just about everything, including your Ship's Gun Strength and Movement Speed, as well as Bullet Speed. The Faster and more Intense/Loud the Music is, the faster and stronger everything is. 

Multiplayer is a Mixed Bag of good and bad however. If for Friends, then Multiplayer can be good. If for the Public Multiplayer, then it's not great. There are barely anybody wishing to play this game Public Multiplayer to begin with due to DLCs making some players better than others, in a bad way, but i'll get to those in the next section. As long as there is an Even Playing-Field for all players, then Multiplayer can be fun. However, that can Rarely happen, resulting in the lack of Public Multiplayer Games atm. This is more of a Singleplayer game to begin with regardless, so don't have Multiplayer be one of those reasons for getting this game.


Now that the main, Overall General Game is taken care of, ONTO THE DLCS! This Section is PARAMOUNT to how much fun you want in your Beat Hazard Experience, so Read up! The best to least needed DLCs shall be listed in order from top to bottom.

First and Foremost, while a situational and very optional DLC, the $0.99 DLC of the Ability to Put extra music-type files into your Beat Hazard Game. TL;DR, For Single Player, and with the very low price of $1 to do it make it the most Highly Recommended DLC to get, unless if the files it's allowing support over you don't use. Even With the Ultra DLC, the game only has 23 Songs, so if you really want to get maximum Enjoyment, The Ability to Stack on Loads and Loads of songs to play on will give Beat Hazard MUCH more Replayability. Again, this DLC will vary from person to person because some may use .mp3 and .wav music files, so it's not needed, but for people who mainly uses iTunes files and what-not, it's a must for them. Something to note, however: the only way you can play Multiplayer with your songs is if everyone else has A: The Same Song name, and B: The Same Song FILE Type (.mp3, .ogg, .wav, etc.) Unless it's for Friends, Multiplayer utilizing this is as unlikaly as you winning the lottery. As stated before, you'll usually want to stick to Friends-Only for Multiplayer, as from what I've experienced in Public Multiplayer, It's not the best.

Secondly, the Ultra DLC. This is the Pack you need if you are looking for all of that Challange you may/may not be yearning for. While it's $4.99, and for a small game like this, the Ultra DLC is quite Game-Changing. This unlocks the Perk System where, if you level up, you can now pick from a variety of Perks to unlock such as ones made to increase Score, obtaining new Weapons such as Micro Missiles and Reflect Shields, and even getting unlockable difficulty levels, which are all VERY useful if you do not plan on getting the Shadow Ops DLC, which will be later. This also gives New Enemies, More Bosses, and Boss Rush Mode. While Boss Rush Mode can, sorta, kinda, a LIIIIIITLE bit be abused to level up fast (which I do Not Condone, nor like, the use of doing,) The new Mode can be quite the experience, and can become Hell-on-Earth, or, in this Case, Hell-in-Space, VERY Fast if you cannot keep up, making it a good challange the longer you survive. This also adds in Co-oP, and Head-to-Head, which is Competitive for whoever can get the most points. While this IS second, it is nearly as needed of a DLC as the Custom Track DLC explained first, with the only 2 reasons of that being Price and Player Skill needed for Ultra.

Now comes the worst of them, and this time an Un-needed DLC that I Do Not Recommend if you get Ultra, and that is the Shadow Ops DLC. The Shadow Ops DLC is, in my theory, the main reason Public Multiplayer is Lacking. From what I have seen from Multiplayer, many of the ships are a Much more OP Version of the Standard Version of the Ship, with the downside of a Larger Hitbox the Majority of the time (exception is the Mosquito Ship). While it may give the game a sense of Completion, it gives Unnessessary Ships that would Kill the purpose of the Ultra DLC, and with a $5 Price tag as well, I cannot recommend this DLC over the Ultra DLC, for 2 main reasons; Bad Synergy, and Less Needed out of the 2. The Reason why the Shadow Ops DLC mixes bad w/ Ultra is that the Shadow Ops DLC makes the game more Easy, as it gives better firepower, killing many of the reasons to even GET Ultra in the first place. If you're good enough, you can, Like me, and potentially many otjhers, complete Tracks on Suicidal only needing the Standard Ship. Even if it DIDN'T make things easier, it sure as heck not making it harder for you. I've seen games where i see people using a few of the Shadow Ops Ships and other Custom ships from the Steam Workshop, and only Rolls with the Reflect Shield, because their ship is so good they don't even NEED the Micro Missiles or Ultra Beams the Ultra DLC Gives, which are two VERY Useful Weapon Perks. If it makes the game that much easier in the higher difficulties, you shouldn't be playing on the higher difficulties to begin with if you wanted a more Casual Play of Beat Hazard, even IF the missions of obtaining the Ships are very Tough, making this DLC not needed if you already have Ultra, which i Recommend Much Higher than this. 

TL;DR: Great Game Casually and Challenging, but not in both worlds for DLC. If need-be, Immedietly get the Custom Song Track DLC ASAP. Do not get Shadow Ops if you're wanting a more Challanging Feel to the Game.

Up-front WARNING:
LOTS OF FLASHING AND VISUALLY INTENSE ACTION!
If you have epilepsy, or something similar, take warning. Bite down on something and watch some gameplay videos before buying.

---

Beat Hazard is a cool twist on Asteroid-style games. Your music (or internet radio!) determines the stage!

Everything from enemy spawning, to your gunfire rate/intensity, to the movement speed of all asteroids/enemies/projectiles, plays off of the music. This makes some songs boring to play, and others nearly impossible.
On a personal note, I definitely feel like any possible music you can grab works with it.

Pros:
+Multiple difficulties, and modes, for any taste.
+Use your music! 
+Tight controls.
+Good visuals.
+Random boss fights, based on music (tempo changes? Not sure).

Cons:
-Niggling to buy the Ultra DLC when you try to close the game, feels like I paid for a demo.
-Limited gameplay beyond the different modes. Would love to see some kind of story mode.
-Small enemy variety.

Neutral:
+-Overly intense visuals can make it hard to tell what you're doing. But, this can be adjusted in the game options.

Very fun way to breathe life into your music library.
Definitely recommended to buy on sale.

Beat Hazard is an awesome way to play your music!

Similar to more popular concepts like osu! and Audiosurf; Beat Hazard utilizes your music library to create a unique gaming experience based on the current track being played. The game itself is a bullet hell/shoot 'em up similar to an Asteroids-style arcade with several different ships to choose from, game modes to play, upgrades to earn, bosses to fight and achievements to get. The dlc bundle includes support for iTunes and m4a tracks, provides more challenges and unlockables to earn and grants access to the creation and use of mods in the Steam Workshop. Though the sprites can feel a bit shallow and you experience some lapses in the fighting, the gameplay and music maintain a level of epic that overwhelms these minor flaws in my opinion. With several hundred songs on my playlist, I purchased the game + dlc for ~$5.00 USD on sale and found it a reasonable price for the content provided.

A recommendation if you enjoy shoot ‘em ups, bullet hells, games featuring your music and if purchased on sale.

My only gripe with the game is that you can only get 1 unlock per song, even if you level up like 20 times. Really sucks to grind out all the perks again when you reinstall the game.

This is a great game for just "blasting some 'tunes", as the youth says, and getting in a quick break from more tedious work.

It's a fun little game I always keep on my PC.
Recommended.

I feel so awful about this game. I'm extremely torn. And it sucks that I have to write such an awkward, ambiguous review.

While I do enjoy the game tremendously and was having tons of fun to start, I quickly found myself reeling with unexpected bouts of headaches and vertigo that lasted overnight after playing. As far as I can tell, there is no way to lower the visual effects low enough to safe levels to allow me to play comfortably. Due to this, I'm currently pending a refund on this otherwise fun, entertaining game.

This caught me massively off-guard, as I have never had a history of vertigo, seizures, or other mental-related issues while playing games. If a way comes to lower the effects to a reasonable level, then I would absolutely enjoy to re-purchase the game, even if I must get it that second time at full price. It's worth that much. But until then, the game may as well be entirely unplayable. It's not worth getting consistent hours-long bouts of vertigo just to play a single game.

The actual game is great, and I would recommend it to anyone who can take the overly-crazy visual effects. This is the first game to ever give me mental issues in only a mere few playthroughs of certain songs, and playing multiplayer with a friend was the breaking point for me. And I can't stress this enough: I'm extremely upset that I am, on a physical level, unable to play this game. I [i]want[/i] to be able to play this game so much. The few playthroughs before the vertigo kicked in were extremely fun and cathartic. The enemies legitimately got challenging during faster paced songs. The aesthetics are beautiful and it's clear that a lot of time and effort went into this game.

However, if the trade-off is severe headaches and dizziness, then I simply can't consider it worth it to me. I won't let that cloud my judgment on the game as a whole, and once again re-iterate in this review that I [i]do[/i] recommend this game at the end of the day. Although this game was clearly not for me, I encourage others to see this game for themselves. If you can take the effects, you'll find a satisfying, simple, and extremely fun game. I promise you that.
Perfect game to play when you have a headache. Be sure to set the visual intensity at 200% for the best headache relieving experience.

[h1]Beat Hazard[/h1]
[b][i]Bullet purgatory more than bullet hell[/i][/b]

[u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u]
Simple and to the point bullet hell shooter with a pretty forgiving difficulty curve. Obviously, [b]Beat Hazard[/b] relies on your having a fairly sizable library of music on your local disk to be able to make the most of the game, so I've not played in a while since I switched over to streaming.

[u][b]Visuals[/b][/u]
Very tight, it rarely feels unfair to die. The screenshots [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/49600/screenshots/]here[/url] are a very good representation of what to expect.

[u][b]Sound[/b][/u]
Music, obviously is your choice. The sound effects are solid and add a weight to the experience without overpowering the music. Not much to say, very good. It would be nice if we could hook into streaming services, but which ones even allow that?

[u][b]Overall[/b][/u]
I'd recommend this as a nice time sink, make sure you have a separate keyboard and mouse if you're playing on a laptop as you [i]will[/i] get cramp on a smaller keyboard and a trackpad ain't cutting it.

Depending on how intense or soft your music collection is, Beat Hazard is one crazy game.

Intense music pushes the limit by adding fast-moving asteroids along with blood-thirsty ships out to destroy you.

You try to score as many points as possible while playing your song. If you make it through, you'll move on to the next. Score point and your rank will increase. Every time you reach a new level, there will be favorable bonuses which make you earn points in larger quantities much faster.

As your music gets more intense, so do your weapons nad the amount of enemies. The flashing lights may be disorienting after a while, but luckily there's a relax mode like in aaAAaa.

The powerups really help you, but I recommend that you clear out the enemies until you go for the powerups.

The boss battles are cool too. Depending on your tracks you're playing, it may produce two mini bosses or one big boss.

If it goes on sale, I recommend this for everyone.

Beat Hazard was one of the first indie games that really stuck out and stayed with me, even after five years. It has a staying power that the likes of Audiosurf doesn't have, because unlike the aforementioned, Beat Hazard has an overwhelming sense of style with the blinding, epilepsy-inducing light show it puts out and the fast-paced carnage that plays like ADHD bullet hell on the higher difficulties, except the enemy ships are the bullets. Audiosurf is more of a pretty looking acid trip with confusing and distracting color-matching mechanics, while Beat Hazard stays true to its concept of an arcade space shooter that turns everything up to eleven and adds some bass boost in the mix. Once the hours you spend into the game pay off and you start to master the highest difficulty, all the chaos comes into place in full clarity, and you suddenly play the role of conductor in a controlled cacophony with a stupidly big grin on your face.

The result is as approachable [i]yet[/i] always thrilling as it is visually arresting and immensely replayable. A combination of classic Asteroids mechanics and procedural generation by music, included in the package are tons of unlockables and power-ups, online play and co-op, modes like survival and boss rush, great additional content, and Steam Workshop.

Simply put, it's one of my favorite indie games of all time, and the best twin-stick space shooter there ever will be, in my opinion.

Beat Hazard is one of my favorite games on Steam.  I've always been interested in the idea of music modifying a game to produce a game where you feel like you play your music. 

And honestly... Beat Hazard isn't that game.  It suffer the same fate as all these procedurally generated music games, like Audiosurf, where the music doesn't have a strong connection to the game you're playing.  When you play Beat Hazard, there is limited connectability to the the music. 

The Music in Beat Hazard pretty much affects the "intensity" of the game.   If you play some music with a high BPM enemies will move at a faster rate than a low BPM.  But even playing Happy Hardcore and other fast BPM music, the game doesn't appear broken, which is a good thing.  A VERY good thing, as I'd hate to see the game limit what types of music it can play. 

In addition, the game comes with a built in soundtrack, something Audiosurf doesn't really do, so at least you can play exactly what song the developer was thinking of when you play the game, and the fact is... it works and by that I mean very well.  There a variety of songs chosen but slow songs have a different feel from fast songs.  That's good. 

But you'll play through the 20 songs or so and then you'll have to play your music?  Right?    Well... not unless you want to, though you can.  There's also internet radio!   At least my copy (which is from the original launch) came with a few stations already set up and adding more is relatively easy, EXCEPT it requires editing a file, so steam boxes and anyone playing in a big picture mode has to go through a few hoops to make it work.  It's not awful, but it's an annoying few steps that I wish wasn't required. 

However the build in internet radio works, and works well, rather than "play a song" you instead play a time battle, 4 minutes up to 20 minutes I believe (and a survival mode for when you want to see how far you can go).  And again, it's YOUR choice.  I chose an electronica station, so I was loving the music and the game, and it worked... really well.   Well except for the fact there's a little disconnect between the game and the song, but you can use internet radio, and listen to great music as you play.

So what's the game like?  It's a bit like Geometry wars.  Rather than fighting geometry shapes, you're instead blasting ships and flying dodging their attacks.  It's quite similar to bullet hell games, but there's a few major changes.  First the game isn't that brutally hard, and gives you multiple difficulty options (including a few you can only unlock through a perk system).  Second, there's power ups.  Enemy ships when destroyed can drop different items, some of them are for points, some of them are weapons you can trigger, and finally there's "volume" and "power".  Power does exactly what you think, it makes your ship strong, however Volume is different.  It increases the sound of the song you're listening to.  At the beginning your music is quite, but as you volume up the sound increases so you can hear your song at full volume.  This also affects the power of your ship (I think defensively) and when you max both you get a special mode, so both of these power ups are important. 

While that disconnect from the music for the game doesn't make this the game I dream of, the fact is the gameplay of the game is fun, and there's a decent connection when you're listening to music and what's happening in the game.  If a song goes from slow to fast and back, you'll notice enemies speeding up and slowing down.  The connection could be better, if you play a song two or three times, it's random how enemies will appear and attack.   However the gameplay itself is solid, and you are able to listen to music you like and have it make a minor effect on the game you're playing. 

But the game underneath is just a fun game.  I love geometry wars, and Beat Hazard I think might actually beat Geometry wars for replayability.  I recommend this game not because it's a stunning success in the world of music games, but because it's a fantastic twin stick shooter with a lot of depth.  The two DLCs (Shadow Operations Unit and Ultra) are both excellent add ons, and being able to get the whole set for under 20 bucks is a good value.

Beat Hazard… What can I say about it? This game for those moments when you want to listen to music but also you want to do something else or for moments when you want an epileptic seizure.

Beat Hazard is a great scroll-shooter, which gameplay bases on a track you choose. Then louder track than more enemies you have (basically).

There are many perks which increase your survivability or score.

But honestly, I don’t recommend to buy this game without DLC. BH Ultra gives you tons of new enemies, perks, co-op, PvP and other cool stuff. Shadow Operation Unit allows you to change ships. 9 new ships + workshop with community ships. SOU opens rank system. With every new rank, you open new, more powerful, ships (obviously).

As a result, we have another great indie project which is like to people who like hardcore and music

Do you like music?
Do you like blowing stuff up?

Well then this is the game for you!

Fancy, Glowy Interactive Visualizer on Steam.

I checked US Prices. It's like... 2 Dollars? I even bought it on sale with 80% Off in my country (With[b] RELATIVELY [/b]similar pricing) , which is absolutely fair. Get it. I even plan to get the DLC this December.

You can literally just plug your laptop/computer into a projector and play this game at a party and no one will be disappointed. Unless you die a lot, which means you can't shoot for the few seconds before respawning, which means the glowy things will stop existing for a few seconds.

Pro Tip : Before playing, you can Tone down the visual effects. On default it's 100% and might hurt your eyes if you play for more than 2 hours straight. Or you could wear sunglasses instead, it's way cooler.



____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Edit : After playing a while, I noticed something. First of all, Beat Hazard 2 is in Beta Access at the time im writing this review. Now, I know, that implies that THIS GAME won't be updated, since Beat Hazard 2 is apparently functionally similar to Beat Hazard, and Beat Hazard 2 is in early access BECAUSE the developer wants to add more features to beat hazard 2 to make it a worthy enough sequel. It puzzles me why the devs couldn't just update this one instead, but I guess making a seperate title would mean more money from the same amount of consumers.



Anyways, I think there's things that can be polished about this game. Specifically, I want to talk about how the selling points of the game clash with each other. Trust me, I know this is somewhat supposed to be both Bullet Hellish Shooter Arcade game, and that's fun, but it's other selling point is it's visual effects and how it can Generate patterns based on sound frequency, much like Audiosurf trying to procedurally create obstacles and boxes based on the music

Problem is, these two selling points need to work together. Our ships shoot a lot of bullets and that's awesome. The default ship can spread based on the music. On top of that, those bullet stream lines vary a lot, and it glows in a very unique way, being suddenly very big and flashy and then shrinking down. Again, according to the beat of the music.


But the problem with this approach is that you can't really see the enemy bullets, which is a bad thing to have in a shooter/bullet hell. I know BH fans would say "The bullets are a very bright red and they have flare-lines coming off them too, they're like red stars with thick lines going out" , but the thing is, our bullets' colors also varies. When purple clashes with red, I can't see the streams of bullets. The glow [b] [i] [u] of our own bullets greatly over-shadow (or over-light) the enemies' bullets. [/u] [/i] [/b]

I know, if I want to see visual effects of my music, first of all, I should just play Chill out since I have infinite Lives. If I want the visuals to be greater, I can pop it up to 200%. If I don't wanna die, just set the difficulty to Easy instead of Suicidal.

But the thing is, SUICIDAL does improve the quality of visuals. The amount of enemy, the patterns they come in and the bullets they shoot ALL improve the hectic-ness of the screen. 
And secondly, I myself bought this game for it's bullet hell aspect. It's a shame that this game is like 80% visuals and 20% "oh, its a bullet hell because you can't see the enemy bullets, which is totally fair game design. if you can't play, don't play". Like no. I play bullet hell games so i KNOW that I can beat this game on suicidal if there were no glowy effects. Again it clashes with the other selling point of the game. If i tone done the visuals and play the game seriously as a shooter, it nullifies the purpose of seeing this as a visualizer/music based glow-program. [b] [u] [i] I want to experience both at the same time. [/i] [/u] [/b]

But I think this can be fixed by doing one simple thing.
It's a suggestion for the developers.

[b] Make these toggle-able options: [/b]

[b] [i] [u] 
-A small, invisible circle around every enemy bullet will not contain glows from our bullets, in the circle's radius
-Enemy Bullets will have a different color than our current bullet color, and changes accordingly when our bullet color changes.
-Enemy Bullets's glowing effect will have a different color than the bullet itself, and a different color from our bullets. At all times.
[/u] [/i] [/b]


This would RAPIDLY improve this game by making it an actual shooter/bullet hell instead of "Oh, the reason its hard is because you literally won't be able to see anything. maybe you should change your settings and game mode"


Still a good game, but eh. I gotta put this out there.
Also again, since Beat Hazard 2 exists, i guess this game just stopped it's updates then. If none of these options are implemented in BH2, I won't buy it. Not even on a 90% sale.

There is a survival mode that let's you cycle through albums seamlessly which is a nice "endless" mode. The longer you survive though the harder and more bullet hell the screen becomes.

You remember that old version of Astroids were your ship was in the center and you shot rocks coming towards you?! Well fast forward into the present and play the same style game with 1 or 2 differences (Very Sarcastic)

1. Full of color (This game looks like someone shot off a whole box of fireworks in close proximity)
2. Your ship can move around all over the screen and in any direction.
3. There are ships, astroids, powerups, missiles, worms,etc
4. The kicker... it is based off your music!  

Before each level starts, you pick a song and difficulty level. Your firepower, the enemies, amount of enemies on screen, and speed are all determined by your songs. (FYI - fast/loud songs are not the hardest). Say you have a song that starts off playing a lot, lots of ships and such come out, you have lots of firepower and life is chaotic. Then you song takes one of those quiet spells. Well the enemies are still on screen but they start to move slow and shoot slow. Unfortunately for you, you also shoot slow. You get the idea.

This can be a very fast game and your screen will be full of color! If you think it can't get any fuller, try playing 2 player with 2 ships fighting off everything. Just remember, all you have to do is survive to the end of your song....

If you buy the entire package, this game will play almost any format song. I even play certain videos for their audio.
Amount of fun is only limited by the depths of your music collection. The gameplay really varies with each song.

Beat Hazard is a Galaga-style space shooter where the pace and number of enemies is relative to the music track you choose at the start. The game allows you to pick your own music - very much like Audiosurf that way - and as you play you can resources you can spend on upgrades, to boost your fighting ability and survivability and increase your score further.

I had a lot of fun with this game, and if you have a great music collection and enjoy space shooters this might be the game for you.

This isn't exactly a review of the game. I just want to point out how bull shit it is that developers can get away with using fake patches to advertise other games. When I click "news" after I see a new patch, I want to see patch notes on what has changed, not "buy our new shit!"

So yeah, every time I see a company pull this, I'm posting a negative review and I encourage others to do the same.

This game is NOT a Bullet Hell, but a Visual Hell.

The enemy rarely shoot you (unless you are playing above Hardcore), but the problem is finding that one particular bullet through the flashfest.

Couple minor problems on ubuntu linux: game uses hardcoded sound device hw:0 in ALSA (possible fix in comments).. also the fullscreen mode does not handle the desktop launcher bar (side) and window bar (top).. Otherwise, this is a decent player for a music library, including OGG Vorbis encoded files. Unfortunately, there is not much for gameplay, behind all the flashing graphics. The developer generously provided a demo - which will really show you the gameplay better than reading this review... hint.. hint..

So, it is very strange that I never got the sense that Beat Hazard used the song beat for gameplay, even in the heaviest techno songs. There were a hell of a lot of flashing lights, that pulsed in time of something, but the enemies' shots never seemed in a rhythm. The flashing lights were pretty at first but eventually headache-inducing. Once I got past the dazzle of flashing lights, I saw there is not much gameplay here, and it feels terribly repeatitive. 

Maybe this would have made a nice screen saver. There is a visualization mode at the main menu, but what would have made it great is a scripted gameplay. I think the visualization mode is nice, and it might even be worth a few dollars to buy. There is no question that the graphics are nicely done.

Additionally, there are a lot of advertisements for DLC stuff, on like basic things like upgrading from the starting ship, online play, and the boss rush mode in single player. And, on exiting, a big, full-screen advertisements reminds you of the game's shortcomings.

All said and done, not being able to configure an audio output on a music game is simply a deal breaker. There are a lot of other little things that I could have looked past, especially with the fine music included, but not with a technical problem like not using the system audio defaults.

Very very cool game. Because you can run your own music with it makes it so incredible fun to play. I would recommend to buy the full bundle because there is so much more to come. The basic game is really basic and have the fucus on the music and not so much the challenge... if you buy the full pack... holy hell that is a blast and is really from 0 to 100 in a few seconds... I love this game its pretty good and the price is worth it.

I know a lot of terrible steam reviews start with "i really wanted to like this game, i really did" but honestly all I can say is that I really tried to PLAY this game and the game TRIED TO KEEP ME FROM PLAYING IT. The first thing that greets you when you open the game is an epilepsy warning typical of most games with any level of visual intensity. I sort of brushed it off as I normally do, and then BOOM THE MENU OPENED AND STROBES STARTED PULSING INTO MY EYES AND THE MENU WAS VERY DIFFICULT TO LOOK AT. This is Beat Hazard's ultimate downfall, the place where it needlessly shoots itself in the face for no reason whatsoever; the game is a fucking eyesore.

There's a niche in indie gaming for games that let you use your own music, with notable examples being Crypt of the Necrodancer and Audiosurf (both of those games are a lot better by the way check em out if this disappointed you), so combining it with a shoot em up is a logical conclusion. What isn't logical however, is combining that with the experience of going to a rave while you're really hung over. Literally for the entirety of the time you're playing the game, painfully intense strobe flashes will be going off originating from every dead enemy, every bullet that you shoot, and I think even just ambiently. This combines with motion blur that occurs when killing a large enemy to make the game's visuals COMPLETELY IMPOSSIBLE to make out VERY OFTEN.

Now, maybe it's just me, but if I can play VR games for a while without feeling sick, why did this game make my eyes literally physically hurt after a measely 10 minutes? Well you see, the game offers a visual intensity score that you can turn up or down. Up offers a higher score, apparently rewarding players who like feeling like they're going to throw up, and down offers a mildly more tolerable experience. I say mildly because even the least intense setting was enough to make me angry enough to write all this. Playing a game that makes you feel physically ill isn't fucking fun in the slightest.

The game would be decent if it weren't for this strobe shit! I don't know why there's no option to turn it off in the graphics! Even the lowest intensity setting makes me feel like my eyeballs are gonna roll out of my head. Why would you design a game like this??? 

So in short, this game is great if you're already blind and don't mind that playing this will make you blind, since you're already blind. If you're not blind, don't buy this game. Imagine the experience of sitting really close to the TV, so close you're almost touching, for the entire time you're playing. It's like that but worse.

Fuck the people who made this. Just go buy Necrodancer.

Intro:

I first played Beat Hazard on my PlayStation 3 about 6 or 7 years ago. I liked it but I only had the demo. So when I found out this game was 80% off on steam, I had to buy it. And, I actually like it a lot more then I did when I played the demo on my PlayStation 3. Especially since you can play to your own music. That’s actually what interested me about this game. But, there are still a bit of problems. 

Issues:

1: I 100% no 105% recommend you don’t buy this game or watch videos of this game if you suffer from epilepsy. There is rainbow flashing lights EVERYWHERE and I am not over exaggerating. 

2: The fact you need a seperate DLC to use songs from ITunes. Look, I get it, the developers probably forgot to put it in the final release, and sure, it’s only a $0.99 DLC. But the point of the matter is that it should of been in the game FROM THE START. 

3: It does have steam workshop, but to use the workshop, you need to buy another DLC. WHY!!!!! Why not let people who get the game normally without all the DLC. It would of been a lot better. 

4: On my computer at least, the game has a tendency to crash sometimes. Maybe because I have too many steam workshop ships? I don’t know.

Conclusion:

Other then those 4 problems, I actually recommend this game. I recommend buying the Mega Bundle because it gives you all the DLC. Just, don’t play it for to long or you WILL go blind by the flashing colours. 

Score:7.5/10

This game has a great concept. Who wouldn't want to play a game generated based on their music? A fun co-op game however only 2 people can play in a lobby as the play field is small. This game does have extreme visual effects which can genuinely hurt your eyes but not even the setting to tone them down really fixes that problem, just be prepared to face that, and this game is definitely not for anyone who is even slightly epileptic. You would probably expect people to play this game with dubstep or techno music, something like that, but actually my friends and i play with metal and scream-o music and it works just as well or even better depending on song of course. I thoroughly enjoy this game as it's a simple but well-executed idea. Ping can be a problem. For some reason it has connectivity problems for my friends and I who can connect on any other game just fine. I will say however not buying the shadow missions DLC could affect your gameplay experience as you'll only get the default ship which obviously is the worst one. Overall 8/10 great idea. On a little side note i found playing this game on controller to be better due to the twin-stick shooter playstyle.

I can see how this game is s lot of fun, however it didn't seem to work properly under Linux, which is the platform I purchased it for.  I am often getting stuck in menus, find myself unable to control my spaceship, regardless of whether I use a controller that works fine in other steam games or mouse and keyboard.  
Regardless of the platform, I don't find the "very positive" feedback justified. The game has a solid concept that exists since the nineteen's without adding much new, except for custom music, which is why I find the seemingly low price of 7 bucks, 13 for the mega-bundle, unjustified.
The custom music also fails to amaze if you use unusual songs with longer parts, during which the gameplay still changes, meaning that you might have to fight an intense boss battle during a calmer sequence if it lasts longer than a minute. 
Content wise, there is little more than a solid mobile game, it even has annoying ads for the mega bundle if you try and close the game.

Beat Hazard is the most badass music game around. Remember Asteroids? The space-based shoot em up collision game? This is essentially a present-day version with saturated (and quite often aggressively pyscadelic) visuals, expanded arsenal, and indie attitude. However, the driving force is of course the music. Your music. Absorb your library into Beat Hazard and blow away billions of enemies (at once) to your tunes until the early hours. As is the most common mechanic within music games, Beat Hazard works with the intensity and speed of the audio source to create the level of action and enemies in the game. As your music intensifies to pulse pounding panic, so does your game situation!

The game supports achievements, leaderboards, matchmaking, several different modes, etc, but most importantly multiplayer. Loading up with a friend and experiencing the thrill of space-based destructive mania and survival to any soundtrack at all is something too easy to get used to every night.

Asteroids controlled by your music? It sound so simple yet it works so well. Much like Audiosurf, it's worth it just to see how the game changes based on your favorite songs. Frantic visuals, swarms of enemies and your own weapons are all tied in to the music you're listening to. A pulsing electronica track produces blinding lights, speedy enemies and blazing bullets for a true "bullet hell" experience, while a soft classical piece mellows everything out. You can listen to whole albums in an endurance mode, individual songs for quick play, or online radio stations. My only complaint is that multiplayer is radio only, but I can understand not wanting to deal with copyright issues from sharing music.

Highly addictive game. I mean, REALLY, highly, addictive. Think like.. 1942 (the oldschool arcade shooter) meets Raptor (similar game by Apogee). Now, give it more modern graphics, and free ship movement, so that you can face and move in any direction, rather than just "up". Play your own music, which in-turn, effects how the game plays out. Add enough flashing lights and colours to potentially give the optically sensitive repetative nasty seizures, and cause the optically insensitive to become bewildered at the sheer amount of everything coming from everywhere (I tend to only play the highest difficulty level, sooo...), and you've got Beat Hazard. Definitely one I'd recommend.

Ranked in the top 20 for the XNA Dream Build Play 2010 Challenge, Beat Hazard is a twin stick shooter that generates its content from the user’s own music library in the same manner as the critically acclaimed puzzle/rhythm hybrid Audiosurf.

With almost limitless replay value and something for everyone, Beat Hazard is a visual assault on the senses bringing to life your music library in a new and exciting way and persecuting lovers of dubstep and epileptics equally.

Still my fave blast-em-up game. Pick an MP3 from your own collection, and the gameplay is tailored to the music. It's insanely fast and twitchy, and it's overwhelming when you first play it. Once you get used to it, though, it's a real pleasure to play.

This game is among one of my all-time favorites. There's a ship for every play style, it's super fun to play with all kinds of songs(find the silliest one you and try it! Even some short audio clips work as well!). It's a very nice pick up and play game, the Shadow Mission dlc is easily worth buying- the missions are challenging without being stressful and passing them feels very nice. The enemies are varied in both design and difficulty. Being able to adjust the flashing lights on the screen helps immensely as well, and the difficulty settings actually live up to their name.

It's definitely not for everyone. If you don't care for music bullet hell games, this isn't for you. Otherwise, I do recommend it. Besides being a fun pick up and play title, it's also a nice time killer to boot. Be sure to look at the workshop for other ship models as well!

I'd rate this game as being not too bad.
You can use your own custom music in the game to play through levels and shoot enemies and such which is pretty neat, but it isn't great. You will need certain music that the game can easily process, a type of music where one or a couple of sounds can be heard at a time rather than multiple. Say EDM or Electro-Swing, where there is one main beat to listen to and then the background music or beats to accompany it. But what it may not do well at recognizing is say DOOM soundtrack or metal music in general, where a lot of instruments are used together rather loudly at the same time. You will usually just get a bunch of enemies alongside firerate when played.
But why am I recommending this if it has what seems to be a big flaw?
That would be because it's concept is fine, it's quite alright, and it plays well still. The original music it provides is pretty nice, and custom songs of your own choice still do work, just takes some testing. Plus the game is quite cheap and even includes a steam workshop where I'm sure you can change up what your ship looks like which is a nice bonus feature.

I've put 13 hours into this game, so I guess it feels right if I review it. 

Overall it's just your run of the mill bullet hell styled shooter, with everything being synced to the music you choose to play. It's a nice clever game with extremely simple controls so anybody can play it straight away with no sort of practise. I enjoy this game but in recent days I've started to hate the game. Why? With the Shadow Operatives DLC you get new ships and missions to complete with those ships. I keep playing one mission and the game randomly kills me, nothing hits me and I die.. the problem is that when I die I lose progress to the mission, and when you're annoyed you quit the song.. which loses you even more progress. 

I started one song with 67% of the mission complete, I die (which loses 1 million points) and by the time I stopped playing I only had 59% complete. 

If you like the game, then congrats. But in recents days and weeks I'm starting to hate the game. I used to enjoy it but then the game started to kill me randomly and that's no fun at all.

Controller: Steam Controller
GPU: GTX 960  
  
To be frank (there's a pun) I couldn't get through the main menu. They warn you at the start that this game has a flashing lights and instense effects and that there is a siezure warning, they even offer an option to back out or continue then with one of 2 buttons. This is the first time that warning was necessary for me.  
  
[THE GOOD]  
The effects seem well done, there are controller options at the start which allow you to choose what your controller inputs are. You can change those later in the options. Music also sounds well done.  The effects go along to the beat of the music.  
  
[THE BAD]  
You start getting a headache 30 seconds in and you start looking away 10 seconds in. There is just too much flashing going on right at the start. I'm not even sure if I can change those settings since I felt like I was getting sicker and sicker as time was passing. Looking away from the screen and I could still see the flashes the room I was in, this is with a somewhat lit room. I closed my eyes, I could still see the flashes. I covered my eyes, and I could still see the flashes. It gets even worse once the rock music kicks up and the flashes become even brighter and more intense and rapid. That brief moment when the music toned down for the beginning of the rock music was a sigh of relief when I no longer noticed intense flashing lights, until the rock reached intensity.  
  
[THE HEADACHE]  
This game might be fun in controls and the beat aspect is a nice thouch that goes to the music. The problem is is that I couldn't even start the game to begin with due to the flashing lights, and that point I didn't even want to due to how irritated my eyes and head felt. There might be options to tone this down, but looking through the lights and flashes more and more made it difficult to navigate. By the end I just wanted to get out of it. This game might have potential, but I'm taking a pass on it.

I saw it: the beginning of the universe. It was dark and then, from the power of my hands, I formed into a steel angel tasked with creating the galaxies and destroying the steel demons of anti-matter. The war was fierce - this war between creation and destruction. This universe is my doing, my hands in a celestrial realm watching, waiting, and ready to dodge their attacks and bring down the dragons of the stars. Many a time I died in battle, but with strength, magic, and power, I was reformed to die again. I was in control, I was responsible for maintaing all life, I was the most powerful entity of divinity in all of the multi-verse. I caused stars to explode and demons to break. I was god!

Then the track ended. Steadily it dawned that I was no god, no being of importance or power. Silence came over me, the stars' flickering dimmed. I was emptiness incarnate...

I was high AF

The mechanics are esentially a homage to the classic arcade Asteroids... except made completely insane by more visual stimuli than the human eye can probably process. The real hook of the game though is that every level is generated by whatever music track you've selected. It's easy to zone out as you steer your little ship through bullet hell while jamming along to whatever it is you fill your iDevice with.

Bottom line is that the game is fun as hell. And it's replay value is roughly whatever the size of your music collection is (although the included tracks are actually quite good). Just be aware of the photosensitive warning at the game's start. This game isn't messing aorund. There will be colors flying everywhere constantly.

Two recommendations are posted here, one for the Shadow OPs DLC and my original one for the Beat Hazard Ultra.

Shadow Operations recommendation (18 Apr 2014):

A very fun DLC that lets you create your own ships, upload the ships to the workshop, and download other player's ships from the workshop. When creating your ship, you can choose from several attributes such as the ship's size, how fast/slow it accelerates, top speed, how fast/slow it decelerates, how strong the bullets are, how fast the bullets move, position of the guns, whether or not you repel or attract perks, how many beams (1-3), and more.  You also get to set up to three missions for your creation so you can make them easy, hard, or a mix.  As you gain higher ranks, you unlock some nice cosmetic attributes such as flares and engine thrust colour. It really is a lot of fun and it gives you new ways to enjoy Beat Hazard.

Any song with the Shadow OPs icon next to it has a chance to spawn what you need for missions. Additional info from a quote from Starg: "The 'play random track' and 'one I've not played before' will also automatically choose a song that fits the current mission criteria."


Original recommendation I wrote for the game (23 July 2013):

I bought this before the sale ended, after having played the demo, and I have to say, it's pretty damn fun. I explode a lot but that's part of the fun for me, destruction to all!!! mwahahaha. Some of my songs have lulls in them where I'm sitting in space twiddling my thumbs getting the Daredevil (and the other one, I forget the name), counting up. I've only played around 26 minutes so far, as far as the in-game counter goes, but it's been fun.

Beat Hazard is a very fun arcade shooter where you pilot a ship, power it up, and destroy anything in your way, all to your own music. The control is great (allows for keyboard or controller) and the effects are pretty amazing, very bright and colorful. Also, there are many additional ships by designers in the Workshop, so experimenting around with other people's ships (and making your own) adds to the fun. The intensity of the enemy waves increases based on difficulty level and the intensity of your music. Obviously, some genres of music will be more preferable than others.

If you're going to get this game, I highly recommend getting all the DLC. iTunes support will obviously let you play your iTunes files, Shadow Ops gives you objectives to complete in the game to raise your rank (allowing you to pick certain ships in the Workshop), and Ultra will add a wider variety of enemies (and probably other stuff, I don't know). 

Overall, Beat Hazard is a fun game that I keep coming back to periodically as a stress-reliever. Sometimes you just wanna blow sh*t up and listen to your favorite music, and this game does a great job of combining them both.

If you love listening to (ostensibly good) music - either from your own collection or via internet radio - while inducing total sensory and dexterity overload, you can't get much better than beat hazard. Top-down, dual-stick, total space-retro-dance-floor-style candy-punk-hipster-rave-strobe insanity at its finest. Horrendously addictive. Only thing that kind of sucks is that, in spite of its age, the devs insist on charging for modular funtionality like multiplayer over the internet, but even still, imho, it's worth it. Check out some videos online to see the madness. Also: the game (depending on the mode you wish to play and which DLC packs you have installed, etc.) can be drastically different depending on the type of music you choose (I like setting it to my own internet radio station on insane difficulty for 10+ minutes.... leaves my brain feeling minty-clean!)... Have had some enjoyable results listening to Tchaikovsky/Classical works from the Late Romantic Era. Which, I'm sure, finally allows such masterworks of expression to finally be appreciated in the setting in which they were originally envisioned to be enjoyed... Cheers!

Along with the currently available DLC's, it adds up to a versatile casual game you can enjoy your music to (Or smack kitties with your keyboard if you try to get all of the achievements/perks/unlocks/whatever).

GAMEPLAY:
The gameplay is rather simple. It's Asteroids with the pace of the game adjusting to the pace of the music you chose. This could be local music or online radio streams (Great Addition, but restricted to the Ultra DLC). There is a little annoying bug which sometimes made my game not play any music anymore when i was playing to radio stations though. Give the game a restart and it was gone. Still annoying.
The game also encourages you to play on until you got'em all. Perks, Upgrades (Beat Hazard Ultra DLC) and Ships (Shadow Operations DLC). If you're a completionist, that is. There is no specific reason to get all the unlocks after all.

I'd give it a 8,5/10 because of the annoying radio bug (maybe only appearing to me) and the replay value (40 hours for few bucks is quite okay i guess).

HOWEVER if you want to enjoy the game to the full potential i would really recommend getting the DLCs as well. It adds up to the game experience greatly as for new, different ships, online radio support, more enemies, more bosses, more modes and so on.

Beat Hazard is quite the interesting game. It offers some rapid-fire shmup action combined with multicolored flashing lights and the ability to integrate your own music library. Altogether, it offers a fast paced, ever changing audiovisual experience.

Yes, the game has its flaws. Gameplay is rather straightforward, and there is not much offered by music integration, aside from some frustration when calm sections result in an extremely weak ship. For many people, the visual effects are too distracting, and in some cases, can cause aching eyes or seizures.

Beat Hazard is not for everyone, particularly those uninterested in shmups and those with epilepsy or similar physical handicaps related to flashing lights. And if your music library is entirely composed of ballads and lullabies? You should definitely avoid this game, or at least think twice about purchasing it before you tire of the games included music selections. However, if you enjoy rapid space stick shooters, have a fancy for light shows, and/or own a decently sized collection of upbeat or high-energy music, then this is the game for you.

This game may be simple, but it is one of the few games that I have never played the same way twice. You have as much freedom as you could possiblyneed, since it is powered by your own music library. Not only is it visually impressive, but the levels of difficulty are greatly matched to give you a wide spectrum of options. 

Most of the fun comes from creating your own challenges and goals. Try going as long as you can without firing your weapon, or only move your ship to the beat of the music, things like that.

This game is fun by yourself, but also has great party game potential. Plus it into the living room sound system, and you got music and entertainment covered

I've played this game for about an hour now, and so far I'm really liking it. At first I didn't get why there was no music on the first game, and then I got VOL's and nearly shattered my eardrums, it's a first time thing, but I think there could at least be a first-time warning. I also began to realize that my music was being drowned out by explosions and gunfire, which can be turned off, but I think they're a bit much to begin with. There are some cool options, my entire library works perfectly (with replay gain, that's definitely a big plus), and this game is definitely worthy of the seizure warning on the front, if you haven't already gathered that. I think this game would be pretty good for passing the time, especially after you get a new album or something. Thing is, I got the entire bundle on slae for $5, and while this is a great game, I would pay the $10, but I really think that should inculde the shadow ops stuff and the ultra stuff as well. The ship creator that comes with shadow ops is very intuitive from what I've seen (I haven't made anything yet), but it looks like you can upload any image and tweak the stats to your liking. Issue being, again, I think that should be built into the game rather than DLC. Visually the game is fantastic, but I think the whole theme could be wrapped together a little nicer, as it's a little all-over-the-place. In game it looks very nice, and I LOVE how the clouds and stars pulse to the music: that aspect is perfect. What isn't perfect is that the enemies don't sync into the music as good as they could, and it seems like, in comparison, Symphony does a bit of a better job, but I've only seen videos, so I can't confirm that. The perks system is cool, but I think there could be more, as your selection is kind of limited, and I also flew through a ton of ranks really quickly (and I'm not super good), so maybe those should be harder to get. Also, it will randomly go through the included music in the menu, which I think isn't.. exactly... adequate.... Overall I think it's a neat casual-to-hardcore game with some great replayability and a price that could come down just a bit.
Why are you even reading this, just buy it. It's a lot of fun.

"Beat Hazard Ultra" - Review

Gameplay:  6/10
A fun game. Modern effects meets old skool arcade gameplay. If Galaga was invented today this game would be it. If you're a fan of the acrade syle or want a bit of nostalgia with a modern twist, then this game is for you. The basic idea on which the gameplay is based doesn't change, but the in-game options, level ups, currency and extras add a little variety to mix it all up nicely enough to entertain. Initially the gameplay feels tricky if not strange and unintuitive, however over time it becomes a bit more like second nature rather than stressful frustration.

Game ambiance: n/a

Reliability/Stability: 10/10
No crash or instability issues to report.

Story/Plot: n/a

Concept: 7/10
Arcade style games like this have been available since the 70's. To think that a new one can be created today, so successfully, is almost astonishing.  The classic arcade space-themed gameplay is offset with the  original idea of not only incorporating your own music playlist, but having the game react and respond to the music. This certainly brings a fun new perspective to this genre.

Concept execution: 7/10
With many features such as multilayer online co-op gameplay with friends, perks, power-up's and a variety of single player modes, this game will keep you busy for a while. Or at least, as lite fun goes, it'll entertain you enough until you decide which major title you want to play next. 

Textures: 5/10
Generally speaking the textures in Beat Hazard are average for a game, but not underdeveloped. You could say they are just enough and nothing more. This can be forgiven however as the focus of this game is more about beat triggered special effects and skill rather than mind blowing textures. 

Modelling: 5/10
Again, the modelling isn't necessarily the main aspect of this game, and again like the textures, it is just enough. They are enough to allow the game experience to be enjoyable and that's the whole point.

Graphics: 8/10
The special effects in this game are dizzying, strobing and seizure inducing. Glorious if you like it, hideous if you don't. Either way you can't deny it's extremely colorful and eye -twitchingly pretty. Turn the room lights off, the screen brightness up and strap yourself into your favorite spaceship!

Sound: 6/10
The sound isn't too bad, given the premise of this game revolves around music. It's what you'd expect from an arcade game but with a more modern production quality. Love it or hate it the volumetric and situational dynamics are there, perhaps a little overdone and exaggerated, but then it does have to stand side-by-side with the huge visuals. If you enjoy shooting spaceships with big audible bangs and explosions then you'll defiantly have fun here. 

Music: 10/10
I have to give this 10/10 for music because it's comprised  from my personally playlist. You will too unless you couldn't care less about music, in which case this game might not be to your taste.

Adjustable shadow mapping: No
Bonus/Extras: none

This is a very straightforward game.  Asteroids/Sinistar 2D view.  One stick flies ship around.  The other aims/fires gunes (at least on a controller).  There's a couple extra buttons for bombs and missiles if you have them, and that's it.

Given the above description, it is positively psychedelic.  Play the right music through it (I prefer techno for the game) and it is hypnotic to play and even just to watch.

I personally found this game... underwhelming.

The issue stems from what the game promises, or seemingly hopes, to deliver to the user. A radically fun experience powered by your own music. The description of the game made me hope to have a racing and heart-pounding experience much like audiosurf, but it felt more like drinking a Red Bull compared to doing cocaine.

To put it bluntly, Beat Hazard is a space shooter. Your lazers, the enemies spawn points, and their flight patterns, are all dictated by your music. You only have about 2 powerups that just change the potency of your weapons, and the volume of your music. You collect money, which is used to buy and upgrade perks, that only increase your score and nothing else. You 'rank up', a leveling system, based on your scores from the songs you've played, but don't get much out of it.

All in all, Beat Hazard is a seizure-enducing, messy, and underwhelming experience. Only electronic music could really fit the game's theme, and the game by itself is entirely obsolete without the DLC. And even THAT is obsolete thanks to Beat Hazard Ultra. The game encourages you to create it's steam badges to get new ships that are only minor changes, and a majority of the fun features isn't available without Shadow Operations Unit DLC.

The game is fun for a length of maybe 15 minutes, while the player holds the mouse button and waits for the level to be beat. The enemies may as well be made of clay, the lights and particles blinding the entire screen, and the explosions even less exciting. Beat Hazard is like taking ecstacy only to be immune to it after it wears off forever.

Going back to Audiosurf.

And be warned, as I noticed. When the music is somewhat slow/soft, so as your bullet speed. But when it gets loud/fast or even accented, that's when your bullet speed is manipulated as it is shot.

I think this is highly recommended for people who love bullet hell genres and interactive-music-simulation games. Or people who love to "modify" the background music to suit their playing style. Ok, maybe you need a more detailed reccomendation than that...
Well, first off, don't buy it if you hate flashy things or are prone to seizures. Seriously. You can turn the intensity down -enough to ensure that you can easily spot targets and hazards-  but not really get rid of it. That would kind of ruin the game- the intense  is both its visual style and its identity, in a way.

It's all about letting the scenes wash over you, subconciously taking in the location of all the enemies, bullets and yourself, while your music swells and dips. If you want to know what this game is think asteroids on steroids to your favourite music tracks. This is my go-to game whenever I just want to zone out and kill some time playing something while listening to music, but don't feel like starting a new game or concentrating on a story, etc. This is my Tetris.

This perhaps isn't the best game if you only want to kill a *little* time, since it plays your music collection (and therefore has the best sound track ever), everytime you say "I'll quit after this round!" it goes and picks yet another great track and you end up saying "Well... maybe after this one!"

What I love about this game is that can be customised to suit your mood - harder difficulties are *HARD*, easier difficulties are easy. The intensity of the game depends on the intensity of the music track you play. You can unlock perks and assign them to help in different ways. After a high score? Put your perks into score multipliers and sacrifice the extra weapons. Feel like a challenge? Assign your perks to weapons and bump the difficulty up (I'm actually pretty good at Suicidal difficulty now ;). Want to just take it easy? Lower the difficulty and put on some relaxing music.

The game actually comes with a decent selection of music from a range of genres, which I discovered while unlocking the Music Tour achievement. Of course it has a fair bit of electronic music, which you would expect from a game like this, but I very happy to see it actually has some decent alternative rock & metal tracks as well. It can also stream music from a number of Internet radio stations (no idea if it's possible to add more), but of course you will really want to bring your own music collection to enjoy this game the most. For me, that's European style Symphonic Power Metal \m/

The perks can be a bit of a grind to unlock, and even more so to fully upgrade them. Unlocking them just takes score, but upgrading them can only be done by picking up in game money - and that only drops $10 at a time. That's not really a problem as the low-mid levels are fairly cheap and is all you need as long as you aren't trying to play on Suicidal difficulty, but maxing them out does take a fair while.

Let's talk weapons. Like most asteroids type games you have a generic laser that can be upgraded by picking up POWer ups. This one is actually pretty good - it has a decent spread and can take out a large number of enemies pretty quickly. The unique thing about this game is the intensity of your weapons also depends on the intensity of the music - picking up VOL+ powerups increases the volume, making your weapons more powerful, but at the same time it also spawns more enemies and makes them faster.

Your second weapon is of course some kind of super bomb, also known as the "OH GOD TOO MANY ENEMIES!!!" panic button to take out most of the nearby enemies and give you a few seconds of invaulnerability. Then you have the reflective shield, homing micro missiles and the Ultra Beam to quickly eradicate a large group of enemies in a given direction. I love that none of these weapons feel like duplicates and they all have their place - knowing which one to use when becomes very important in the higher difficulties.

You remember back in the nineties how games used to have warnings on the box & the first page of the manual not to play them if you suffer from epilepsy? Well, I do. Anyway - I think this game actually means it, it uses a lot of very intense strobing visuals which (other than causing epilectic siezures) can make it pretty hard to see incoming projectiles - when I first started playing half the time I couldn't see what had killed me. The visuals can be toned down (or increased to epic proportions!!!), but personally I kept them on 100% and just got used to them.

If you are going to buy this, get the Beat Hazard Ultra DLC - some of the stuff I mentioned here is specific to that DLC and the base game does not have a huge amount of variety in terms of enemies, weapons, etc. The only reason not to get the Ultra DLC is to try it out a bit and see if you like it. As soon as you are convinced, buy the Ultra DLC.

----------------
Even Katy Perry
Becomes Intimidating
In this shoot em up
