REAL REVIEW: 

Without hyperbole, probably one of my most favorite games to ever come from my time using the steam account. I grew up on a healthy diet of asteroids as a kid as well as G Darius/R-Type/etc. Vertical and Horizontal shooters are my thing. This game doesn't dissapoint. 

Even though I haven't played it for close to a year and only dabbled with the ultra version for a week or two, I will say there is a lot of content to keep you coming back. The main appeal is that the levels and enemy frequent/type/etc are all generated by your music. This means infinite replayability, plus it's just a blast to play. 

I liken this game more to a 360 degree bullet hell more than a shoot em up. The difficulties are nice and balanced. If you want a challenge, you will find one on the hardest difficulty at the largest intensity you can crank the game up to. 

All in all, you will get your money's worth if you like shoot em ups/bullet hells. Be careful though, as the game can strain the eyes. Take a break after an hour or two.

One of the best music based games for Steam. This game and its developer know what the goal was for the game. And thats a relaxing game but yet challenging for all sorts of gamers. The game includes arround 8 songs to start beating on your enemy. The Beat Hazard Ultra DLC adds arround 5-10 more enemy types and bosses. If you want to pick up the game get the complete pack.
It's a bit like Asteroids, but with music. Somehow this is supposed to be a good thing, but I just found it boring.
Holy shit!! This game is fucking amazing <3 !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

10 minutes (about 2 and a half songs) in, I had to quit the game because the sheer awesomeness was giving me a headache. Music has never been better than with a light show, and this game throws in fucking fireworks just to show off!

Normally I play shooters like this for about 5-10 minutes and get bored.  But the custome soundtrack feature makes this game.  Plugging in stuff like Daft Punk, Crystal Method, and my favorite video game OST's make this game a blast.  Though I did have to turn down the screen effects.  It's hella seizure inducing.

This game is frantic, fun and old school arcade.
Use your gamepad, if you don't have one, buy one to play this game.
You will get crazy of the flashy graphics. Remember the warnings for seizures in console game manuals? Take them serious at this game.
If you can stand the flashy graphics, than this is one hell of a game.
8/10 Very fun to play

Haven't tried the Big Picture mode with it yet, but I think this is a game which benefits from that mode. 
I will update this review when I played it on big picture on my tv.
They helpfully point out "Gameplay Powered By YOUR Music!", as if your taste in music is the reason this game is a boring, shitty slog of tediousness.

Fast paced and visually exciting, an arcade style score attack game that will have you saying "just one more try" long in to the night. Feeling tired? Drop the difficulty and this is a great way to just relax and enjoy your extensive music collection.

Fast Pace, mind melting light effects and the ability to play a different round each time you pick a different song; Beat Hazard offers infinite replayability accompanied by fast action and crazy explosions.

Miss the old days? Playing those space shooter arcade games? Well fear not because Beat Hazard is here better than before since the Ultra update.
The gameplay is the legit old day space arcade game BUT! The better part is that you get to play while music runs on the background as the enemies, the meteors and your ship firing rate is all in sync with the song while you get to watch a blinding show of lights and explosions.
So what are you waiting for?! Go play your favorite songs!!

Almost unlimited replayability with it's laidback approach to the "arcade space shooter" genre.
Give your music library a new twist with this!

my eyes hurt

I was once one of the all time top players in the world in this game. Not because I was especially good but because I played it a whole lot. 

They have options out there to lower the visual intensity which definitely helps because I was getting some crazy eye twitching going on before they added that setting.

BEat Hazard Ultra is worth getting by the way, without it the game seems kinda lifeless, with less enemy variety and weapon variety. With it, it allows you to really customize the way you play it which I think is great.

THe only really bad thing about Beat Hazard is that it doesn't have Audiosurf style song specific leaderboards, and what they have in place of that is sorely lacking. But the game itself is fun enough that the leaderboards don't really matter as much.

By the way playing on any difficulty lower than Insane is just boring. Suicidal is nuts and I don't expect everybody to just jump into that but Insane is basically perfect.
awesome
Awesome game.  I love my music but rarely just sit and listen.  Having a game that not only natively plays my music but also reacts to it is spectacular fun.  Highly recommended!
Asteroids + Music Player + Rave = FUN!

+
Action-packed, especially if you load a fast-paced song.  Since adding the "Ultra" DLC to the package, the game also exhibits a more diverse array of enemies.  Great game for people who love score attacking.

-
It's not the kind of title that most people will turn into a major project, and could potentially get tiresome if played too often.

Beat Hazard is branded as a musical bullet hell powered by your music, but it's really no different than loading up your favorite bullet hell game and turning on your own music in the background.

It really does seem the ONLY thing that affects the gameplay is the tempo/intensity of the music. Slow bit? Slow enemies. Fast bit? Faster enemies! Everything else seems to happen at random, like boss battles, the spawning and location of enemies and their types, ect. However, most of that can be changed by the difficulty of the enemies, rather than changing the song. So what does the music do? Well, it mostly gives intense seizures, but that's a common thing.

It's still a fun bullethell game, and it's fun to play it all with your favorite album blasting in the background. It's also one of the VERY rare music games out there that support online play. If the game can match two of the same MP3's on each other's computer, you can play together. Very simple, and works really well... if there's not much latency between you and your opponent.

The game is very extensive and has lots of modes to keep you playing for a long time, but if you're looking for a game where the final amazing "fuck shit up" shot is timed with the best part of the song, try something else.

Trippy space battles with your music blaring in the background. 

This game is a fun joyride at lower prices, but most people won't get any more than a few hours out of it, before they grow bored.

This is a game I definately suggest you wait for it to go on sale, before buying. Also keep in mind that trying to add too many tracks to the game library, actually seems to crash the game. A pity. I only got to about 4,000 tracks before mine started crashing.

Awesome game, if you love blasting your music.  Challenging and fun, difficulty levels are well blanced.  Graphics are nice, but can be a little hard on the eyes, but there are options to turn the intensity down.   All and all a good game if you want to kill some time listening to music.

Powered by YOUR favorite music! This game is badass - as long as you don't have epilepsy! You play as a space ship and rack up points by blowing up the enemy ships in time to the beats of your favorite tunes. I went from being frustrated at first to beating every Achievement, I love it! Even more fun than the other music powered game (Audiosurf) in my opinion - highly recommended for music lovers!

Fun, IF you can take the seizure-inducing fireworks explosion light show.

I don't mean that as a challenge either. Totally serious. You know how some games throw in the seizure warning at the back of their instruction manual just to cover their asses legally in the off chance that one person is playing their game who just might have a problem with it?

Well Beat Hazard puts that seizure warning up front and center before you even start playing, and please pay attention to it. If there were ever a game that was going to make good on the part of that clause that says "Even people who have no history of seizures or epilepsy....." then Beat Hazard would be the game to do it.

Even on the lowest visual intensity settings, the game is still very flashy!

--

Alright, so you are sure you aren't going to have a problem visually with this game? (Watch some youtube clips first or something before you buy).

Then you're probably in for some fun times. There's a lot to like about this simple yet enjoyable twin stick shooter that plays off of YOUR soundtrack!

The concept is simple enough, survive to the end of the song, dodging enemies and blasting everything that moves all the while. Your scores can be posted and compared, and while I think it is rather silly that turning down the visual intensity in the options has the potential of lowering the score you receive....unless you are a hardcore competitive type, then I doubt this will be much of a concern to you.

You can snag score multiplier pickups and bombs to help clear the screen in tight spots, and weapon powerups as well so you can increase the potency and versatility of your shots.

On longer songs big "boss" ships arrive and start blasting lasers all over the place, and they can be a handful sometimes, especially if there are still a lot of the smaller cannon fodder chasing you around and limiting your manueverability, but that's all part of the fun.

I would recommend this game more readily were it not for the intensity of the visuals, as-is I can recommend it with some reservation. It is fun, yes, but visually demanding because of all the intensity of the flashes and strobe effects.

Not much to say about a shoot 'em up, huh ? But, well. Here it is. Playing your own music and customized levels is badass, you know ? If you get really good, it is nice to achieve Suicide Mode. I recommend playing with the X-box pad, movements are more fluids, I would say. Enjoy !

You like music + you like Asteroid-like games = you'll love Beat Hazard!

Beat Hazard utilizes your own music library to generate unique waves of enemies and bosses. While gameplay isn't very deep (earn money to unlock new perks, no real campaign), the unique perk system adds some variation to the game[lay style. You have limited number of perks you can activate, resulting in loadouts that are designed to achieve high scores that sacrifice staying power, or heavy-hitting ones to get your through the harder difficulties without getting as high of a score.

Using your own personal music library with varying difficulty levels gives this game almost endless replay value. Different genres of music will affect how powerful your weapons are, making slow moving, quiet songs relaxing and amping up the pressure during fast, action-packed heavy metal or dubstep. 

The only real issues I have with this game are the inability to redefine X-box controller keys (which are somehow different on Mac and Windows) and manually entering some custom settings in a text file in a certain location. Granted, some of those settings can purposefully reset your scores if you want, but some (like ConstVolume or ThanksButNoThanks) seem like they should be accessible through the in-game options menu. 

Overall, this is a really fun game. It looks really amazing when playing in the dark and having your room light up like a rave, and online multi-player makes competition fun as well. I recommend it for people who enjoy twin-stick shooters and like listening to their own music while blowing up hordes of enemy ships.

PROS
+Gameplay varies based on what song is playing
+Online Multiplayer
+Re-bind keyboard controlls
+X-Box Controller Compatible
+Unique perks system

CONS
-Manual settings file
-Can't rebind X-box controller keys

Beat Hazard is a fun twin stick shooter where you select a track from your music library as your level selection.  While playing, you'll hear the track you selected and the enemy waves will be generated based on what you're hearing.  It happens in such a way that a given track will always play the same, allowing you to learn and get better at a specific track.

The graphics are great, and the gamepad controls are perfect.  If you don't have a gamepad, you can attempt to make due with mouse and keyboard controls.

Beat Hazard is also the only game I'm aware of that has in-game rewards for crafting its Steam badge.  You unlock a ship skin with the level 1 badge, the level 5 badge, and the foil badge.  These ship skins are purely aesthetic changes, though the width of the firing pattern does vary slightly between them.

DLC:
Beat Hazard Ultra completely transforms the game and makes it better in every way, adding more enemies, more bosses, and a perk system, as well as making enemy waves far less predictable.  Highly recommended.

iTunes and m4a support is only necessary if you have music in these formats that you want to play.  Otherwise, you can ignore this DLC entirely.

Shadow Operations Unit adds extra ships to the game with different stats and their own separate leaderboards, and Steam Workshop support for creating and sharing your own ships.  Each ship also has a set of missions (read: challenges) to complete.  Highly recommended.

As a gamer, this is probably my new favorite way to enjoy my music. The gist of this one is that you can select your own music files to "play", which adds personality and variety to your game. It works like so: You choose a directory where you keep your music, and you can select any and all music on your computer to play with. Once you select a track, the game loads up and you're in. It should be noted that the visual effects are seizure-inducing (the game warns you this when it starts up), but this is not a problem for most people. I got past it after my first couple of games.

Playing a certain music file is like playing a different "level", albeit with very similar enemies. Most of the time you will fight a "boss" ship towards the end of the level that will have a large amount of health and some very dangerous weapons. During the fight, small enemy ships may attack you as well. The best way to deal with the boss is to try and outmaneuver its weapons while keeping it under your concentrated fire.

It is kind of a difficult game, and it resembles a generic arcade shooter. You have a small ship with a decent amount of firepower and a set number of lives to begin with. Taking a single hit will cause you to lose a life and most of your powerups, but some of the lost powerups drop in the middle of the screen in a cluster and you will have a few brief moments of invulnerability, allowing you to pick them up when you respawn. Power and Volume are your best friends in this game; they increase the amount of guns you can have going at a time, and the intensity of the damage you deal out, respectively. 

You will notice that the visual effects as well as your damage increase quite a bit when heavy bass or loud, sharp tones play in your music. This makes it ideal for dubstep and metal in my opinion, but as long as your music has a sick beat and a high enough volume, you should be fine. The visuals can be distracting at times, such as when your music becomes more intense and everything gets two or three times brighter. This makes it harder to see what your enemies are doing, but picking up on certain visual cues will help. One such cue is that one of the main indestructible projectiles that is fired at your ship is always red in color, and is always round.

Even if you don't want to play the game, you can use the game's built-in visualizer in "Chill Out" mode to just listen to music and watch your screen do its thing. It actually is pretty relaxing.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys listening to their music, or even just likes arcade shooters. In my opinion, it is worth the money whether you want to blow stuff up or just kick back and relax. If you're lucky enough to pick it up while it's on sale, it is a total steal. As long as you don't run out of music, you will not run out of fun with this game.

Beat Hazard is a arena dual stick shooter or arena shump if you prefer; mind you seeing how it's for PC is more or less keyboard and mouse shooter but don't let that take away from what this game actually is or dose.

Graphically this game isn't anything special (let’s be honest this isn't the reason why you play it) it's the visuals; oh the visuals are just amazing due to it being a "visualizer" it does just that. Remember Apple's and Microsoft’s visualizer or maybe you're one of those people that still put that on. What IF you wanted to play a game in that cluster f***? Well you can!

Controls (I personally like the keyboard and mouse so I mostly know them) are smooth and responsive as hell, the keyboard controls the ship and abilities, the mouse fires and also uses abilities; they're fully bindable. The controller plays just as you expect, one control stick controls the ship and the other fires in the direction, the abilities are used with the triggers (I think).

The gameplay is well... you’re put in an arena; you listen to your music AND YOU SHOOT EVERYTHING AND EVERYONE UNTIL YOU GO BLIND or YOU DIE. Sounds simple enough, well it's just that honestly. Depending upon the song this can be easy as hell or so hard you just wanna kill someone! The online is a bit weak due to "you must have the same copy of the song" due to piracy; co-op isn't bad; I only really played an hour on co-op.

While the game is fun and awesome there are some things that just fall flat on its face. The fact that Ultra is DLC; this isn’t a bad thing but compared to the original the Ultra DLC offers WAY more in content and gameplay, I’m not saying the original isn’t fun but it comes across kind of lame in comparison… at least for me, there are quite a bit of people who just like the original more. Once you beat the game, level to the highest level and get all of the achievements it offers very little to come back to. Some bullets are VERY hard to see considering what it is and that’s the point but sometimes you’ll be wondering what just killed you!? The games difficulty is great and all but it also leads to certain songs being balls hard while some easy as hell.

This game is one of my favorite music based games and it’s completely fun but it offers no reliability or even an incentive to even come back to, some may find that not such a big deal considering the price of the game but once you’re done… you’re actually done… of course there is a leaderboard so… there’s that I guess. The visuals are great but can lead to mystery deaths. Songs can be way too hard or way too easy, sometimes you can’t find a middle ground. Is the game worth it? Yes, but I love music and at times play games with my music. This game really depends if you can stand a lot of visuals, love music.

If Asteroids and Audiosurf hooked up in the bathroom of a deadmau5 concert while high on ecstasy, nine months later they'd give birth to Beat Hazard, the bullet hell game in which seizure-inducing lights are weaponized into a laser cannon for the most psychedelic space battles ever witnessed.

This game has great visuals and gameplay that is a throwback to the old school game called Astroids. The vallina game has upgrades that allows you to gain more points and make the fights more intense as you decimates entire waves of eneimes depending on the the song you used as well as the difficuty. The Ultra DLC is a bounus to the basic game by adding "Perks" for you to buy and choose depending on your play style. It also adds more types of enemies into the mix that makes the game more challenging to play. There is also new weapons for players to destroy enemies with which includes: Ultra Laser, Homing Missiles, and Ultra Shields each lasting for a few seconds. The games modes include Standard play, Endless mode, "Chill Out" mode which has infinite lives and no score, and Boss Rush Mode(Ultra). It even includes local and online co-op. It is also helpful to buy the iTunes and m4a support DLC as well.

Please note that this game (just as like as any rhythm/music game in general) is limited to the amount of songs you have in your library. As playing the same song over and over again will get repetitive even if the online leaderboards give the incetive to play the same song again to get a high score. 

The options here are little left to be desired as the visuals here is quite stuning and flexable when running on older PCs. And the config file outside of the game have a few more advance options for the user to create. There is also rebindable keys and buttons for controlers which support. There is an option to use last.fm if the player has not many songs to choose from. 

Beat Hazard is a great alternative to the well known Audiosurf and can provide tons of fun and challenge to the player in a top down twin-stick shooter fashion.

Bah. No wonder I haven't played this game in so long, or very much. I love music, and this was supposed to be a awesome way to get immersed into a game with your music. It gets a big "No, it's doesn't" from me. With the other noises going on, it's a huge distraction from what using your own music in this is supposed to do. The single worst thing that enflames that aspect though, is the volume power-ups. So, even if you start out with something huge and blasting, well, too bad. It's going to play it softly until you collect the power-ups to make it louder so that you can actually hear the music that you put on. On top of that, it often doesn't matter , since sometimes when you blow something up, it dips the volume for a bit anyway, as if it needed some kind of sidechain compression between the music and game audio for some reason. Completely breaks the immersive experience, and so the game just comes along as feeling cheap and gimmicky. Especially since, without the music hook, there's nothing that makes the game stand out. Go buy Audiosurf. It's also very simplistic, but if your looking for a game where using your own music actually adds something to the experience: It's much better.

Beat Hazard, A game that is literally "Powered by your music". Beat hazard is a game in which you pilot a space ship and avoid incoming enemy attacks from missiles and lasers to rockets and crashing. Your weapons are powered by your music as well. Have a silent song, and your gun will be weak, have a loud song such as heavy metal, and you will be blasting enemies from all directions, but sometimes, you need more than just big guns. Obatin powerups such as superbomb to eradicate enemies or get out of a sticky situation. This game has inspired me to dive deeper into the music industry. The game also has a Co-op or Head-to-Head feature. Team up with your friends in taking enemies down, or see who can take on more, and rise above all others. But there are some enemies, that cannot be taken on alone....

This game is trying to combine a 'bullet-hell' arcade shooter with a game that reacts to and changes with a chosen music file, and honestly, it is mediocre at both.  
A few specific examples of things I don't like about the game:
- When you die, your ship drops a number of powerups.  There have been many times where I've died early in a level, and ended up better off for it because of the drops (I've even had my score multiplier increase after dying).
- The levels are randomly generated, even with the same song, so high scores per song are basically meaningless.
- As far as I can tell, the only way the game 'reacts' to your music is by slowing down the enemies and your fire-rate (and weakening your weapons it seems) during slow or quiet parts of songs.  A major downside of this, is that for songs that are slow and/or quiet by nature, it is nearly impossible to kill anything because your bullets are so weak and shoot so slowly.
- A side note, if you don't like games with excessively bright and flashing lights, do NOT buy this game.  I have the visual intensity set to 25% and it is still a seizure on the screen.

All that said, if you want an arcade shooter whose soundtrack is your own music library, then this is the game for you.  Although you'd be better off buying a real bullet-hell game, muting the game's music, and playing your own.  If you want a game that generates levels based off of your music tracks, then check out Audiosurf.

I don't know how I played this back in the day, as it's not that great of a game. Asteroids meets Audiosurf is fun, but the latter does a much better job of showing how your music actually affects the gameplay instead of "Well I guess this means time for a boss just as the music slows down so I can't shoot jack crap?" The visuals are incredibly noisy and, while stunning for a while, get tiring as you die again and again because it's literally impossible to even see your position on the screen. Sure you can turn down the visual intensity, but you also take a sizable point detraction for doing so.

The ship you use controls nicely but is preposterously slow, and I often found myself dying due to that as well, as opposed to Beat Hazard Classic where the ship is much faster but somewhat slidey. You'll often find yourself haphazardly sprinting about when you get to a slower part of a song and your screen becomes approximately eighty percent space junk and asteroids (which are extremely annoying and often not worth shooting due to the chaos it causes), and a faster ship without the slipperiness of the original would have been perfect.

Negative ten points for immediately giving me an ad about cosmetic ships for badge crafting rewards on startup, but plus seven for letting me get rid of it just as fast.

Speaking of which this game is refusing to give me trading cards despite owning it for years, although that's neither here nor there.

RPG games are my forte, but I do love me a music game. 
I define music games in two branches; those that have strict music and those that have freedom. Both have their qualities, and are fairly equal but Beat Hazard Ultra brings something.. new to the table.

Essentially it's a top-down shooter, space themed. Your mission is to shoot enemies - that spawn based on your music, using weapons - that spawn based on your music, combining multipliers - that spawn based on your music, to gain masses of points - that increase based on your music.

The theme here is obvious.
Now many games afford you those kinds of perks(!) already, but BHU has another trick up it's sleeve; Online Co-Op. 
It's a great feature that most games these days needs to include, and BHU does it with minimal fuss. Sure, both players need the same music for it to work in most cases, (sometimes they don't? It's a weird system..) but the point is, it has it and it works -damn well-. 

A game as challenging as you make it.

Pretty awesome rhythm-based game, where the songs on your own hard drive determine your gameplay experience.  Anyone familiar with Audiosurf or Rhythm Zone should understand the concept.  

What you get with Beat Hazard is essentially a really fun, effective mix of Asteroids and Audiosurf, complete with great, vibrant graphics, high replayability, and fun gameplay.  Each song you play will generate a different experience, with your guns and the enemies getting stronger and quicker as the song gets faster and more intense, and will also generate boss fights randomly throughout.

Beat Hazard comes with single player, two-player, online co-op and competitive multiplayer, and lots of perks (upgrades) you can equip in your ship's slots, tailoring the game to your style.  Really enjoyable game overall, and worth it if you have lots of songs on  your computer.  There's a demo on Steam, so check it out!

For those of you (like myself) who just can't fully mesh with the Shoot 'em Up/Bullet Hell genre, Beat Hazard makes for a safe compromise. Pick a track from your music's library and fly through space in arcadey fashion. The intensity of your ship's lasers and agressiveness of the environment are determined by the song you play. Oh, and there are powerups. And bosses. 

Who knows? Practice with IOSYS's remix tracks long enough and maybe someday you'll be man enough to actually play Touhou.

Picked this game up on a steam sale. I didnt have high expectations, and it seriously hit me with a surprise. See, when you turn Beat Hazard on to play a game of it, you shoudn't expect highly complex gameplay, or intense story. In fact it doesn't even have a story, you are controlling a spaceship, and you have to shoot asteroids and other spaceships from a top view perspective, just like the old arcade games. What makes Beat Hazard special is, all of this is happening to music. Your chosen music.

When you start up Beat Hazard, the thing you should expect is crazyness. You shouldn't search sense, just shoot and enjoy the music that you chose for your shooting. The visualizer really gives you that "crazyness" feeling, and the rate of the incoming enemies is also somewhat related to the tempo of your music. 

I mean... This game has a powerup that literally just pumps your music volume up... What do you expect then?

And I recommend playing with maximum intensity visualizer for extreme "crazyness". Of course if you are sensitive for that kind of thing, be careful.

-more fun

Cons:

Definitely recommend picking it up at least on a steam sale, but be sure to get the DLCs too.

This game is one of those hidden indie diamonds in the rough, how so?

the game is overall straightfowards, you have a ship versus a near infinite amount of enemy ships in fast paced laser-gun combat at the beat of whatever background music is playing.

while the above sentence could easily apply on many other twin-stick shooters out there, it stands out on this game in particular due to it's core mechanic:

Gameplay powered by YOUR Music.

there are many twin-stick shooters out there, but all restrict the player on whatever powerups you may pick what levels you play and at most provide you with a few catchy tunes along the way,
this game however manages to go the extra mile and provide support for your music and even better base it's entire core mechanic around it, how so?

the strength, intensity, speed and visuals of nearly all elements on the screen while you play are directly affected by the intensity of your music. 
if your music library consists of heavy beats, then the game will crank enemy spawns and spazz-inducing visual effects like there's no tomorrow, the downside to this however is that having a mellow music library does the opposite, reduces enemy spawns, light intensity and overall speed of the game.
(which by itself, isn't so bad if you're looking for a break in the action or cannot handle strobing lights)

The fact that this game uses your very own music library is also it's best point, as if you're one of those guys that cannot help but have more than 20 GB of music stored on their hard drive, then you've basically given yourself hours and hours of free DLC, in the end, it's up to the player to decide how active or dull their experience with this game is.

moving on to the ships,

as of the last update (shadow operations DLC) the player can now change between different ships, now to be honest, this is merely just an extra for those who wish to give the default ship a break, these newer ships provide either greater mobility or firepower and sometimes even auto-fire or auto-pickup for items. all in all the extra ships are made for people who are either having a tough time on the regular game or want a self-imposed challenge by selecting (or creating) a weak. slow. ship. You're not missing out on much should you play with the regular ship.

which brings me to the next point. Ship Crafting.

If you're one of the players who just doesn't want to customize the music, but the ship as well, you now can with the previously mentioned DLC. you are given a set of "points" that you can use to spend on designing your ship.
you can go for heavy and strong or light and nimble. you're pretty much given a good set of options on how to build a ship, the kicker is, PNG support, what makes your ships unique is that you can in a way draw your own ship, customize it, THEN play with it, all in all, a pretty cool feature if you have the patience for it.

FINAL VERDICT: If you're into shoot-em-ups, and love music-based gameplay, this game is for you.

AS A BONUS: This is one of those games that actively benefits from soundtrack bought from other steam games such as TF2 or Half Life. if you by any chance have any game albums downloaded, give them a go with this game you might be surprised how some tracks play out.

Beat Hazard is a twin-stick shooter that creates challenging, entrancing waves of mobs using your music library as a seed.
Score is awarded not only on difficulty and chain, but modules equipped and willingness to stare blind-eyed at a fluorescent cacaphony. No, really. You get a score multiplier based on the VFX slider.
The basic game has a good sense of progression and the DLC missions added a great deal of focused replayability. 
The achievements include such things as marathon play of a Christmas-themed internet radio station, and by the end of your run you'll learn how to dodge like a zen master or spend 99% of the time that matters invulnerable.

More than anything else I've played through on Steam, this game was my pot of tea. If I could give it two thumbs up and pre-order the sequel, I would.

This is a new take on the classic asteroids game with music. What defines it apart from every other clone of this really old game is that you can use radio stations, the in house music, or your own to have your tailored experience in which no one else will be able to reproduce without that musical piece. There are five difficulties in which the lowest has the least amount of enemies on screen and allows you to virtually stay in one place while playing on the hjighest difficulty there will be so many enemies on the screen  you will be constantly forced to move out of the center of the map just to get that maximum bullet spread. Do be weary of staying on the sides, as just with the orignal game it is spawned out of, enemies will pop out of the other side in which you cannot even do. The difficulty is also controlled by the tempo of each of the instruments and keeping to such the enemies, your rate of fire, thier rate of fire is all controlled by that so hold on to the seat of your pants and find the highest bpm music you can find. The electronica genre is very good for this type of adaptive difficulty.


However, there are a few minor flaws, just like almost every other game in its genre since the SNES days, and that is once things get crowded enough you cannot even see the bullets that are being hid behind all the strobing light effects, explosions, and everything else flying around the screen. This would not be so bad if turning the intensity of the effects didn't also effect the intensity of the light of the bullets being shot at you.

Overall, I would recommend the game.

If you're looking for an intriuging and challenging audio-synchronized experience, you won't find it here. Beat Hazard is instead an isometric space/arena shooter that paces everything, from the intensity of your fire to the pacing of enemies to the seizure-inducing screen effects, to the intensity of your music.

It's a pleasant game for when you want to zone out and enjoy sound and color. There's not a lot there, but it's a pleasant enough game. You're more likely to die in many cases from having trouble determining which bright flashing thing is going to kill you than from legitimate in-game challenges.

"Shadow Missions" and perk unlocking add a mild sense of progression to the game, but otherwise no storyline or plot exists. I enjoy the game as a sensory experience, rather than an immersive otherworldly indulgence or hyper-challenging gameplay quest.

Disclaimer: I have only ever played Beat Hazard Ultra, since I got this in a bundle. I will only be speaking about Ultra and the Shadow Operations Unit DLC. It’s possible most of this review will only be relevant to Beat Hazard Ultra.
Also, if you have a history of epilepsy/seizures or anything related, pass on this game. Seriously.

Beat Hazard is an extremely visually intensive shoot em’ up music game. You pick a mode, pick a song, either your own or from the supplied ones in the game, and then you play it. Enemy ships spawn, with some accordance to the intensity of the song. You shoot them with your incredibly flashy weapons. If listening to your music and shooting enemy spaceships while lights flash a ton sounds appealing to you, then great. This might be your game. There’s also controller support! (I recommend controller if you can. It’s very nice.)

There are a pretty decent amount of options when you play a song. You have three initial difficulties, Easy, Normal, Hardcore, and you can unlock Insane and Suicidal later on. Visual Intensity can be set to 50%, 75%, 100%, 150%, and 200%. (These do affect score, but honestly 200% is very difficult to look at, with only a 20% bonus.) Finally, there are perks. And there are a lot of perks. Score boosting perks, item perks, and sub weapon perks. 

The four game modes are…
Standard: Playing through one song
Survival: Playing for a long as you can while the game cycles through songs
Boss Rush: Fighting bosses on a timer before more spawn, as long as you can, while songs cycle
Chill Out: All perks unlocked, infinite sub weapons, infinite lives, no score, no currency earning, casual playing

The Shadow Operations Unit DLC is an alright buy. You gain access to more ships, including Steam Workshop ones, and you can make your own as well. Each ship plays differently, and it’s a nice change of pace. However, I will say the Shadow Missions are incredibly… irksome. Death penalties can be difficult to overcome depending on the mission, and some missions are just difficult to begin with. You can absolutely opt out of the missions, since they’re just there for achievements.

A few people call it a rhythm game, I strongly disagree. In my opinion, rhythm games are defined by a strong correlation of the song with the gameplay. For example, in Crypt of the Necrodancer, your movement is meant to be linked with the beat of the song. Beat Hazard isn’t really like that. The closest you’ll get is if the song intensity dips down into nothing, and then comes back up. It’s not really related to the beat.

Do I recommend this game? Yes.

Beat Hazard is, well... Insane, to say the least. If you watch someone experienced playing the game on the hardest difficulty, you'll see what I mean. 

Lights flash, ships explode, and wave after wave of enemies relentlessly piles upon you, all to the tune of whatever music you choose. The harder difficulties have a near-vertical learning curve, but once you have mastered the game, it is one of those games you can just pick up and instantly feel awesome about.

The Ultra update is worth every penny. It makes the game easier in some ways, harder in others. The new bosses are tricky and require different tactics than what classic BH players are used to to beat.

In short, it's an unmissable game, unless of course you can't handle the bright strobing effects, which are way more intense than any screenshots would have you believe.

Beat hazard a top down Shoot'em up, but unlike other Shoot'em ups there are no levels to memorize, because the game generates game play based music, much like audio surf. If you like the Shoot'em up games, and you like the idea of audio surf, then this might be the game for you. and i challenge you to try your favorite comedy routine.

Being able to play a game using your own music isn’t new, but being a good one is hard. Beat Hazard lets you select your own music and then uses the tempo to create difficulty spikes and flow of enemies. The beat of the song is scene in the bullets you shoot as well as the crazy explosions one screen that can give you a seizure. When you select your music you get to decide the difficulty. Pick a heavy and fast metal song and you’ll be lucky if you get through the whole thing. Pick a normal soft rock song and the difficulty is very gradual.

When you actually start shooting there are several power-ups that range from increasing the volume, shot power, money, and bombs. If you die you can collect the stuff your dropped, but if you keep collecting the stuff you get more and more powerful. You can use the money to buy perks that range from power-ups when you start, extra lives, and other various perks. There’s a good amount and it’s worth playing just to unlock them all. However, the game doesn’t have much depth so this is a 30 minutes-at-a-time game or you will get bored. The visuals are decent, but the special effects that flash around remind me of Geometry Wars on crack.

So this is once again a game that makes you the decider of how fun of an experience you get. The engine underneath does a good job using the songs to great a fun space shooter, but I would liked to have seen more power-ups or maybe something more 3D. If you don’t like 2D space shooters you won’t like this even if you get to use your own music. The game can get really hard quick and can be a bit confusing at first until you get the hang of it. There are quite a few modes such as multiplayer, boss rush, and endless mode so there is some variety there. For the low price you can’t really go wrong so pick it up and enjoy the craziness!

I’ll be honest, I haven’t spent too much time in this game, in fact, today I decided to go through my reviews for music driven games to add certain things, and I realised that I have had this game since 2012 and not even written a review for it yet.

Beat Hazard is a new spin on the old “asteroid” type genre. This bullet hell game includes levels that are tailored around your own music, you move your little ship around, and shoot beams which act as a kind of visualizer to the music. It’s really pretty, but it’s also a very visually loud game, and I can imagine you would need to be in the right kind of mood to properly get into this game. If you suffer from epilepsy, perhaps avoid this one.

What makes this game a little more interesting than your standard bullet hell type game though, is that you can level up, unlock new perks and customise your ship. From what I can tell, you are rewarded for playing this game, which isn’t always too common in the music driven genre.

The most attractive feature, however, seems to be the difficulty aspect of this game. Like those guitar hero videos you see on super mega extreme difficulty, you can really get this game to be crazy if you pick the highest difficulty mode, and choose a really challenging song. 

It may seem a little weird that I’m writing a review for a game that I have barely played, it kind of is, for me this game is a little too loud and flashy, but I can definitely see why this game was so popular. Despite me not having spent any real time in it, I still want to recommend it as a decent music driven game. As far as the genre goes, there are a fair few of the same. There is a lot of runners/on track games, and at least this one is a bit different.

There is now since a Beat Hazard 2 out, which I don’t own yet but can imagine that it’s worth looking at too.

All in all, I shouldn’t really have much of an opinion, but I do. Despite not being 100% my cup of tea, it’s a decent game, it’s well made and it’s something a bit different in the music driven genre. I’d say it’s worth a go, so perhaps give this a try, or even just look into buying the second one.


TL;DR : Basically it’s pretty loud and flashy for me, I’m an old lady, it gives me a headache. At least it is something a bit different in the music driven genre, it’s well made, and I can see why it was so popular. Give it a go if you want a music driven version of asteroids, or even look at the second one.

Achievements: No multiplayer achievements.  Both DLCs (Ultra and Shadow Operations Unit) are required for 100% completion.  

I purchased the epic bundle that included both DLCs.  I can't properly speak towards the quality of the base game alone.  

I love music driven games.  For a long time, though, I was too intimated to purchase Beat Hazard.  The screen shots on the store page made it seem so noisy and cluttered that I was worried I wouldn't be able to parse anything happening.  I am very happy I ended up purchasing the game despite my fears.  It is a lovely way to experience music.  

The combat is hectic enough to be challenging, but mindless enough to be relaxing.  There's a satisfying sense of progression as one ranks up and earns upgrades.  The player has the option of choosing from a range of different difficulty and visual settings depending on how intense they want their experience to be.  The ships all felt unique and helped to vary the gameplay as well as provide new sets of challenges in order to rank up.  

Getting all the achievements took me ~19 hours and I never felt like earning them was a grind, so I think it's priced pretty reasonably.  

I'm not typically a fan of shoot 'em ups, but this was really fun.  I didn't find that the flashiness of the visuals detracted from the gameplay, but you may have a different experience.  I recommend you check out the demo if you are hesitant about purchasing.

Beat Hazard is one of the best rythimg bullet hell games out there. The game offers tons of replayability since you can play as much songs as you may have in your computer. The fact that you can also play radio stations on it is a nice plus.

The graphics are the spicy thing. The game offers you a slider of visual saturation for the variety of visual effects that the game offers up to a maximum of 200% visual saturation. What does this mean? you may ask. It mean that your screen is filled with tons of flashy blinding lights of several color through the whole song that you are playing. This madness is event greater in high beat songs during survival mode because there is no end untill you rant out of lives.

The game offers several perks for you to complete a song besides shooting from your ship. Micro misiles are this little flashy homing misiles that your enemies used to shot you but now you can shoot them too. The ultra beam is a high famage ray that is useful for clearing lots of enemies. Super Bombs are a massive explosion that clears a wide area of the scree. These come with other perks that let you increase the amount of these items, more multipliers for higher scores, more multipliers for not dying or not shooting, and even more lives and more.

The game is as difficult as you want it to be. It can be easy peasy lemon squeeze in easy with 50% visual saturation and increased lifes and increades super bombs with increased shields. Or it can be a cluster f**ck in suicidial with 200% cisual saturation only three lives and a ton of micromisiles and ultra beams to destroy everything and blind yourself in the process.

The game feats several leaderboards, achievements thay you can compare with your friends, three gamemodes, trading cards, and freaking workshop for more ships in case the ingame ones aren your thing. Its just a good game.
Everything about this game is great.

A music based Asteroid clone with full screen strobing light visual effects. Be forwarned. This game will induce seizures, or at least a very bad headache within 5 mins of playtime.

Gameplay is simple. Shoot anything that moves. Graphics are just psychedelic. The whole game just bursts with colour and light. It feels exhillarating to have a cool and fast techno tune blasting in the background while the world explodes in colour.

The game makes uses of music to generate its difficulty. You can either use the ingame music supplied, or use your own custom mp3 tunes. If you find it too difficult to play using a hardcore techno tune, try switching to something a little slower paced.

Good diversion for a couple of minutes of time wasting, but only if you can stand the horrible headache after you put the game down.

Overall Rating: 6 / 10
Buy it only if on sale and ONLY if you are willing to endure a splitting headache after you end the game.

A space shooter that can get very intense, very quickly, especially on higher difficulty settings and with rock/metal/synthwave/meme music. There are various modes through which you can experience your music: from a boss rush mode that may have you bashing your head on the wall trying to get past wave 30, to a mode where you're overpowered and nothing can stop you...except enemies. Those can still kill you. But you have infinite lives so who gives a shit!
-People who are sensitive to intense visual stimuli should stay as far away from this game as possible. Even the title card you see in the Steam Store before your purchase could be enough to cause permanent eye damage, with side effects such as seeing flashy cosmic lights every time you walk down the street. 
-But for everyone else, you can adjust the visual intensity in the settings! And feel free to enjoy the marvelous Space-Shooter Bullet-Hell that is Beat Hazard :)

[u] [h1] [b] Overview [/b] [/h1] [/u]

Beat Hazard (Ultra) is a music-based game that centers around music, primarily your own playlists, often via iTunes or other media libraries. The game itself has you piloting a ship (or one of many with DLC) whose goal is to score as many points as necessary within the length of any given song and to avoid dying. You'll face enemies ranging from stray asteroids and basic enemy ships, to mines and even bosses in the form of large monsters or battleships with a multitude of weapons at their disposal.

 The game rewards you for staying alive by supplying you random powerups and score multipliers that dropped from defeated enemies. If you die, which you can by being hit just once, you lose some  of your powers and score bonuses. At the end of the song, your score is tallied and as you score more points, your piloting rank will increase. Increasing your rank gives you the option to select bonus perks, weapons or even extra lives based on your play style.

The difficulty can be adjusted based on two parameters: The song you play and the base game's difficulty. Since the game's pace is based on your music's pace, speeding up and slowing down as the music does, creating a different play through for each song. You can also ramp up the challenge by selecting "hardcore", "insane" "and suicidal". I found "hardcore" to be a nice base for causal playing if you're looking for something that won't stress you out. "Insane" is great for a challenge and "Suicidal" is, well, suicidal. If you're looking to test your reflexes, it will show you no mercy.

 In my eyes, the visuals are what make this game so enjoyable. Even with roughly 40 hours of game play done at the time of this review, the visuals have yet to bore me. The visuals, much like the pace of the game, will fluctuate between slow and erratic, constantly changing colors. Players can adjust how strong they want the color effects from the ingame menu, helpful for those with sensitivity issues or that have a difficult time determining enemies from balls of light in the background.

 While your overall enjoyment and replayability may differ, the game is well polished and provides comfortable atmosphere and challenging game play. I've enjoyed every moment of this game.

 [u] [h1] [b] Pros [/b] [/h1] [/u]
[list]
[*] Music - The game syncs to your media library, offering you as many songs to play against as you have.
[*] Track Diversity - The waves of enemies you meet and the pace you meet them changes on each track, keeping you on your toes.
[*] Visuals - Colorful, bright (sometimes too bright :P) and, frankly, pretty to watch.
[*]Challenge - The game can offer a constant challenge.
[/list]

 [u] [h1] [b] Cons [/b] [/h1] [/u]
[list]
[*] Without music on your PC, the game would be a shell of its former self. Aside from internet radio and a few built-in tracks, you'll not find much fun after a few play throughs. Having your own music is highly recommended.
[/list]

 Overall, if you're a fan of music-based games, then I'd highly recommend looking into Beat Hazard.

So first purchasing the game, it seemed to be quite a refreshing buy from my norm, and it's good to get out of one's comfort zone, but not like this. I cannot sit through these kind of visuals, it's unimaginably bad. Big random particle effects are not fun, they strain the eyes. But when you turn them off, you see the games dull interior. Stock ships and static icons to go around. I tried playing the hardest mode to see if the ships really could be differentiated, but alas, no. Even if the artists of the game make each ship a different color, they would still look the same.


That's on top of the fact that they use the same ships over and over again. There is one scout ship design, but there could be 30 of the things on the screen. It just looks ugly. But when you get to a boss, that's the really kicker. They start to shed hundreds of the same little yellow and red triangle looking thing, until you get to the gross interior of this thing. It makes it even worse by the very black background. Puke green on black, awesome.


The meat of the game comes from it's one gimmick: your music fuels the game. Yeah right, more like background music to boring game play. I put in one of the most techno songs I had, it had a base drop and everything, and the game didn't even follow the beat of the damned song! You put in "Marry had a little lamb" and you still wouldn't know how the song and game play correspond. The ships come in at random, and you shoot them. I thought the lasers would of had a beat to follow the song, but no. Nothing of the sort came my way, only disappointment.


This game is nothing but a bunch of static images shoot particle effects. This game should be for like 2 bucks, but it's 10. Plus, it's necessary DLC, Shadow Operations Unit. That. unlocks the steam workshop and missions. It might of done something else, but not as far as I got. The first thing I looked at before even playing the game was a logo that looked like it was made in MS Paint. It was an unskippable text cut scene that felt like 15 minutes.


I was genuinely surprised that some of the most basics things to a game were DLC, which made me wonder when the DLC came out. Turns out Shadow Operations Unit came out 4 YEARS after the games initial release. What? It took these smucks 4 years to add missions and a leader board? That's horrible. M4A file support wasn't even available at launch. (just as a side note, there is an option to play the game in classic mode, but I couldn't even get that to work)


But wait! There's more! The game didn't even work for me for the first hour after buying it. It kept crashing, so I had to go find the file, and change it's properties, and then create a different file to put in the roaming folder to make it windows and HOLY CRAP. I should not have to do this much computer work to make a game work properly. Even after that, the game still crashed during game play. I am running win8.1 and even games that ran on XP work, so this is inexcusable.


If you skipped down to the bottom to get my verdict here it is: it's bad, eye straining, and doesn't even work properly. Everyone should treat this game like it's a hazard.
Now I know what epilepsy feels like.
Multiplayer and file format support has to be bought extra? This is just shameful. Other than that, you can have 1 or 2 hours of fun, gets extremely boring over longer periods though.

A solid shooter, not exactly dependent on music. Music intensity affects the spawn of enemies and your firing rate, slowing to a crawl in silent parts. It's nice to play with your music, but this isn't Audiosurf-style interaction. I know the meme is to play with high visual intensity and abuse yourself, but just turn the visuals down to 50%. I wish there was a lower setting than that, as the visuals just cloud everything. No one cares what setting you use.

New weapons make tracks more interesting, but the progression system makes the game hardest at the start. I wish there was a difficulty option between Hardcore and Insane, as there is a fair amount of time where you don't have the ship upgrades to reasonably beat long Insane songs, but Hardcore becomes too simple. The Shadow DLC is compelling, adding new ship options and support for auto-fire ships to further increase the variety. However, the DLC does not change the musical interaction, so the gameplay is identical.

It's easy to pick up and play, and pretty enjoyable. There's good replayability in theory, but I don't think the shooting is varied enough to come back to it regularly after finishing off all the challenges. Audiosurf has more gameplay options to keep things fresh, but this is still an enjoyable shooter with all the DLC. I'd say $10 USD for the full package would be a great deal, so 30% off everything is pretty fair when that happens.

In the end. I can recommend this game if you have some money in your steam wallet which you don't know what to spend it on, if it's on sale, or you are just curious. A game where you take any song, and it dictates the speed and content of the level. It's a top-down dual-stick shooter that seems to take inspiration from Asteroid and others.

Each song is it's own level, and you can use mp3 songs, ITunes songs, not sure what other formats though aside from those.

You want more levels? You get more songs and you play them. In addition to this, the DLC allows you to access more ships which play differently (essentially allowing for an entirely different playstyle with certain ones) and gives challenges to aim for, and the other DLC adds in 100% more stuff. Imagine with this last DLC, that you took beat Hazard and added one new thing for every old one.

So Beat Hazard's DLC is entirely worth it in my opinion.

There are powerups, Damage and Volume. One makes you do more damage, and the other increases the song's volume which gives you many benefits alongside more projectiles and more damage aswell. Max them both out, and you go into Beat Hazard mode, which makes the game WAY easier to kill things.

You die in one hit, so it is VERY challenging as some challenges require to never die in a song on high difficulties.

You gain Exp in the amount of Points you gain (you get 1000 points on a song, you get 1000 Exp) and there are ranks/levels, but only Shadow Operations ranks really dictate what you have access to.
Ranks do dictate the giving of perk points however.
There's Elite ranks that go on for forever, they're more for bragging rights more than anything.

You can put together playlists of songs in the game you can listen to randomized shuffles of your library that go on and on until you die, or you can even listen to a radio station until you die, like the christmas radio station, which provides challenge greater than all my Dragonforce and Metallica songs (I have about 19 metallica, and 6 dragonforce songs).

Only special abilities and enemy attacks use sounds, but nothing really is every louder than the music, unless you set it accordingly.

So... I recommend this game, it's great fun for it's price, the DLC is priced very well in my opinion, and so long as there's always music, there's always levels for this game, so content is potentially unlimited. Basically an interactive music player, blast enemies as you listen to your tunes.

There are a lot of twin stick shooters out there nowadays and Beat Hazard Ultra is my absolute favourite. The addition of various new bosses, mini-bosses, weapons, and game modes really rounded out the experience and made it feel like a complete package.  Highly recommended.

Beat Hazard Ultra is a solid space shooter that runs off your own music. The game pace ramps up or down based on the music's pace. Your ship fires a kind of deadly colorful laser / bullet stream mix, and its intensity varies on the music as well. The game's effects are very vivid and very expressive of the action. For their chaos, they *are* consistent to what's going on (mainly you destroying hoards of various ship types and dodging everything else) and you can adjust the intensity of the downright euphoric effects.

   You earn money and point ranks as you play the game, which grant you perks and the ability to level them up. These may add score bonuses, extra lives, instant starting power-ups, and special weapons (shield, micro-missiles). The many perks to unlock along with the very pretty visuals will keep the player coming back for more, while the large difficulty range and endless music possibilities will ensure many different players will find something they enjoy.

Pros: 
Solid code that works well with lots of different kinds of music
Great artwork
Adjustable features such as brightness from 50-200%
Use your own music
Fun to play and challenging

Cons:
No mouse control on menu
Navigating to music folders is tedious if you have a large HD like I do
Workshop only available as a DLC

The only real con I have a major problem with is the last one. Deciding to make the workshop available ONLY with DLC was a LAME unnecessary and greedy choice for this developer. Workshop content can keep a game fresh and new thus keeping it alive with community driven content. Making this a PAY feature was a very poor choice and I can only hope other developers don’t start a trend of making the workshop a pay feature as well. 

That aside, the game is fun and coded expertly and at times just amazing to watch.

[olist]
    [*]loves music
    [*]listens to your own music while playing games
    [*]likes flashing lights
[/olist]

If you answered yes to most of those things then you might enjoy this game.
Beat Hazard is a visual assault of light strung together with fleets of ships flying at you from all directions, all of them trying their best to shoot, push, pull, ram and surround you till you die. Fortunately your small little ship is packed to the brim with firepower and you get to navigate your way throught the onslaught that is your favourite song. All this packaged together makes it a very adictive game that you can just pick up for a few minuites or a few hours depending on how you play games. Not to mention the perk system will have you trying out different combos of score boosters and weapons for ages.

All in all I would highly recomend this game to anyone who loves their music.

Are you a fan of Geometry Wars? Did you enjoy Audio Surf? Are you an old school fan of Galaga or Gradius? Well guess what? YOU HAVE ALL THREE IN ONE PLUS ADDITIONAL EPILECTIC SEIZURES! No but seriously, don't play if you have Epilepsy. 

That being said, this is really a great game. There's a good number of ships, the perk system is really nice, the game play is a lot of fun, and the browser for tracks is nice (Although there really could be some form or organizing/sorting to easier find tunes in game. But they included a Windows Browser option for that so I guess that works). You need a serious case of ADHD to keep your eyes on your ship though, as it tends to get lost in major battles filled with colorful explosions. but truly, this game really has no downfall. Everything it offers is there, the fun is nonstop, and you can even download user made ships as it's compatible with Steam Workshop.  The only thing I would change is adding some more diverse enemies (there's about 20 or so enemies in total including bosses). 

All in all, the TL;DR of it is that this game is worth picking up.

Out of all the games I have played that are musically driven, BeatHazard is the greatest. It made listening to music a fully immersive experience by appealing to my tactile/kinesthetic habits, and provided equal visual stimulation. To have 3 out of 5 senses fully engaged on an intense joy ride was awesome. 

I habitually retun to this one. It's just too damn good.

Developed by Cold Beam Games in an underground bunker where a separate team was trying to resurrect Jesus Christ. This may or may not be relevant.

A game so utter in its simplicity, yet so GLORIOUS in its execution, Beat Hazard has resulted in thousands of murder-suicides across the globe, the perpetrators generally reasoning that the rest of the world is now "just one big letdown". The game is a source of untold joy, having brought the wonders of synesthesia and/or ocular hemorrhage to you kids at home. It has shown entire generations the true meaning of life, and, in one case, actually caused a blind man to see again, albeit in an enitrely new spectrum not known to mankind.

In summation, the game is the beautiful love-child of Asteroids, Geometry Wars, Audiosurf, and an epileptic seizure in a neon paint store. Spend the ten bucks, you cheap dou­che, and your eyeballs and your ears will love you forever.

Or you might go blind. It's hard to tell.

Incredibly fun twin stick shooter. Lots of lights, colors, and MUSIC. I played it at a friends house and decided to buy it myself and use the music that I like rather than his. I loved playing this game and getting the achievement. Being a game based off of music you really need to enjoy listening to music to play it. The music is pulled form your computer (itunes usage is available through a cheap dlc) and there is some pre loaded music that the game comes with. So if you have no music on your computer you'll either have to use the internet radios it gives you, download some music, or just use the couple of songs the game provides. The Shadow Operations Unit dlc does add extra ships to the game each with advantages and disadvantages of their own, but it is not neccessary to fully enjoy the game. The Beat Hazard Ultra is not absolutely needed to play the game and enjoy it but I highly recomend buying it if you can, even better buy the bundle and get all the dlc for the game and get the full experience. The only downside to the game is that by default settings the SFX sound is turned up rather high and the sounds of the game tend to become to much for me to enjoy the music and lightshow it provides, this is simply fixed however by turning it down to a lower level and the SFX are hardly noticable anymore. Very good Twin Stick SHMUP

One of the best music driven games. Graphics may be somewhat lacking but the psychedelic seizure inducing strobe effects help to cover them up while providing an extremely satisfying light show in tune to your music (or the rather good music that is included). Game play is fast and fun twin-stick shooter with influences of bullet-hell, where enemy patterns and boss encounters are all determined by the music. The Ultra expansion as well as the Shadow Operations add plenty more content which very nice if you plan on playing the game for an inordinate amount of time on it, though the Ultra expansion is the better and more necessary DLC. Pick it up with the full game for cheap on sale
Great
Want an arcade style game with your favorite music as the power source? This game is for you!

Simple, casual fun, in the form of a twinstick shooter played to whatever music you like - and you get powerups in the form of "volume up". What's not to like?

Well, here's a couple of things:

- Pretty thin base game. Should have had more special weapons (only has "superbomb" and the ordinary ship weapon) and more perks. The enemy types (including boss types) are pretty limited as well. It really feels like they stripped away content from the game so they can sell it to you as DLC.

- Lots of colorful explosions are pretty, but make it hard to see what's going on sometimes. You WILL die without knowing why every now and then. 

Still, I really enjoy it. Enough to buy the DLCs at full price actually.

My recommendation: buy it on sale, and get the Ultra and Shadow Operations DLCs at the same time. (Consider the bundle.) But only if you are ok with that it is a casual game without any real sense of progression, except for a few unlocks and the achievements.

Surprisingly entertaining and enchanting game! Also - it's one of the most beautiful games I've seen - in its own way. I absolutely love it! Consider it a creative way of listening to your music - or a way of falling into some sort of trance :P The shadow missions with the different ships are also loads of fun!

Only downside is that you can't connect it to your spotify account, so I had to download all the songs I wanted to play :)

Don't let my low Steam hours fool you. I had this game when it originally released on XBLA and I have over 100 hours invested AT LEAST.

To be straight forward, if you like old school over-the-top space shooters and shooting enemies to your music then this is the game for you. Not only does it come with some decent tracks to rock enemies to, you can add in your own music to the mix and really have a great time listening to your music and gaming.

The difficulty can be adjusted to suite you as well as the visual intensity so it can be fun for any beginner or expert player. Not to mention the various game modes included such as Survival where you keeping going as long as you can survive or Boss Rush where you continuously battle boss after boss, which is a real blast!

That can also be PLAYERS because the game features a COOP mode that allows you to play the game with a friend on the couch or online. You can play with the music provided or, if you both have the same tracks, your own music. There are also some other more competitive game modes as well.

There is also Steam Workshop support for cool new ships to download and play with which is a neat little feature to check out.

This game is what you get when you mix Shoot-em-up with artificial intelligence that reads the intensity of your musical track and spawns enemies to the rhythm. It's really fun! The entire game beats to your music, and when it peaks, all of the explosions, weapons and enemies peak as well, meaning you get that high rush from your music and the game as well.

[h1]Simple idea, flawless execution[/h1]
I've played countless hours of Beat Hazard before, so my playtime can vary. With that being said, this nice little game is a great way to listen new songs, favorites, backlogs and whatnot all while engaging in some frantic and/or cozy shoot em up experience (depending on the difficulty setting of course). Not just that, the many game modes (i.e. multiplayer, boss rush, survival) will drastically increase what already has the potential to be well over hundreds of hours of enjoyment. I also loved how you can buy new ships, perks and upgrades in-game, even though veterans don't need all of that. For them, I'll simply suggest to embrace the idea of a shmup fueled with your own music; which can be both nostalgic and modern at the same time. While for newbies, and even those who don't like the genre, give it a chance. You could at least appreciate the arcade-y feel of it, let alone the whole gimmick.

[h1]Just get Beat Hazard 2[/h1]

It's hard to give this game a negative review. I mean the game plays according to [b]your[/b] favorite music.

However there are a few things to notice :

- If you want to be able to play online you gotta pay for the DLC.
- If you wanna finish all the achievements, pay for DLC.
- Want more upgrades? Pay for DLC.
- Want to access workshop items? Pay for DLC.
- Want to show off your score on the leaderboards? Yes, even for that you gotta pay.

I enjoyed the game without those things, it was something unique when it first came out. But the things mentioned above are features that every game has for free. Maybe except the upgrades and achievements part.  It feels like the game has been cut to pieces. It would be wise to merge the DLC with the main game.

I first bought Beat Hazard more than 7yrs ago on a disc from a discount store. I have played it many, many hours because its modest price doesn't reflect how good it is. Lots of games and electronic toys interact with your music collection in some gimmicky way, but Beat Hazard really interacts in a recognizable way that is a cut above cheap toys and cheesy games. The levels and enemies spawned by your music collection will provide hours of enjoyable and challenging game play.

The Steam version is a remarkable improvement on the classic version,adding support for a variety of audio formats that were unavailable when this game was released on a disc 10yrs ago. I have a vast music collection, but was limited to only MP3 files in the original classic version. The improved Steam version supports almost any file format you can think of plus a variety of streaming music services. You have nothing to lose by trying this game out for yourself. Go blow some up some enemy space ships using your favorite song as ammunition.

[h1]"Sam & Max: Beat Hazard Bonanza"[/h1]

Characters:
- Sam (a dog in a detective suit)
- Max (a hyperkinetic rabbity-thing)

(Scene: Sam and Max are in their cluttered office, surrounded by various gadgets and random items. A computer screen displaying "Beat Hazard" is on Max's desk, and Max is enthusiastically playing the game.)

Sam: (leaning against his desk, sipping coffee) Max, what on earth are you doing over there?

 Max: (wildly excited, not taking his eyes off the screen) "Sam, I’ve discovered the most vibrant, volatile, and violently visceral thing in the history of virtual violence in video games! It’s called Beat Hazard!"

Sam: (raises an eyebrow) Beat Hazard? Sounds dangerous. Is it radioactive?

Max: (laughs maniacally) Nah, Sam, it's a game where you shoot things to the rhythm of music! It’s like a disco for trigger-happy maniacs like me!

(On the screen, spaceships and asteroids start moving to the beat of a catchy tune.)

Sam: (looking at the screen) Well, I’ll be darned. It looks like a psychedelic light show on steroids. And it’s giving me a headache.

Max: (still shooting and dodging) That’s the beauty of it, Sam! It’s a visual and auditory assault on your senses! It’s like the ‘60s on turbo mode!

(Suddenly, Max's spaceship gets hit, and a “Game Over” screen pops up.)

Max: (disappointed) Aw, beans! I got distracted talking to you, Sam!

Sam: (smirking) Distraction or not, you still got your furry tail handed to you.

Max: (presses the restart button) No worries, Sam. I’m going back in, and this time, I’m bringing the funk!

(The game resumes, and Max starts shooting and dancing in his chair.)

Sam: (shaking his head) You know, Max, this game may be mindless fun, but it’s a bit too flashy for my taste.

Max: (grinning) That’s the best part, Sam! It’s like playing a game inside a kaleidoscope!

(As Max continues to play, the music builds up, and the screen becomes even more chaotic with flashing lights and explosions.)

Sam: (squinting at the flashing screen) At this rate, we’ll need a seizure warning and a priest.

Max: (gleefully mashing buttons) Nonsense, Sam! The only thing seizing here is my unwavering thirst for pixelated carnage!

Sam: (deadpan) And here I thought caffeine was the most dangerous stimulant in this office.

Max: (dodging virtual explosions) Nope! It’s unfiltered chaos with a side of bass drops!

Sam: (watching Max’s frantic gameplay) You know, Max, if you fought crime with half this enthusiasm, we’d actually solve cases.

(With a final flourish, Max’s spaceship clears the level.)

Max: (proudly) "Ha! Take that, you barely-rendered, partially existent alien scum!"

Sam: (applauding sarcastically) Bravo, Max. You’ve conquered the digital universe. Now can we get back to solving real cases?

Max: (exhilarated) Oh, absolutely, Sam! But first, let me just break my own record one more time.

(Sam rolls his eyes as Max dives back into the game, and the room fills with the sounds of pew-pew lasers and Max’s maniacal lau

Beat Hazard: A Rhythmic Explosion of Fun

Beat Hazard is a game that seamlessly fuses the excitement of a twin-stick shooter with the rhythmic allure of music games. Developed and published by Cold Beam Games, Beat Hazard offers a unique and mesmerizing experience that keeps you coming back for more.

Gameplay: The core mechanic of Beat Hazard is brilliantly simple yet infinitely engaging. Your spaceship's firepower and the intensity of enemy waves are directly influenced by the music you're playing. This means that no two playthroughs are ever the same. Whether you're blasting through intense rock anthems or cruising to mellow electronic beats, the game dynamically adjusts to create a challenging and exhilarating experience tailored to your music taste.

Graphics and Sound: Visually, Beat Hazard is a stunning spectacle. The screen lights up with vibrant explosions and pulsating visuals that sync perfectly with the music. The game's aesthetic is both chaotic and beautiful, turning each level into a unique light show. The soundtrack, of course, is only limited by your personal music library, allowing for an endless variety of gameplay experiences.

Replayability: One of the strongest aspects of Beat Hazard is its replayability. With the ability to play any song from your music collection, the game offers virtually infinite replay value. Additionally, the online leaderboards and various difficulty levels provide plenty of challenges for those looking to test their skills and compete with others.

Customization and Modes: Beat Hazard also includes several game modes and customization options. You can tweak the visual intensity, choose different ships with unique abilities, and even dive into a robust boss rush mode. These features add depth and variety, ensuring that the gameplay never feels stale.

Community and Support: The game has an active community and the developers have been responsive and supportive, providing updates and listening to player feedback. This has helped maintain the game's longevity and appeal over the years.

In summary, Beat Hazard is a fantastic blend of music and gaming that offers a unique and highly enjoyable experience. Its dynamic gameplay, stunning visuals, and endless replayability make it a must-play for fans of both twin-stick shooters and rhythm games. Whether you're a casual player looking for some quick fun or a hardcore gamer seeking a new challenge, Beat Hazard has something to offer. Dive into this rhythmic explosion of fun and let your music guide you through an unforgettable gaming journey.
