[h1]Blasting bosses in the Darude asteroid belt![/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] The gameplay is simple to learn, but difficult to master.  Memorizing the various boss patterns & strategies, learning when to use your super weapons & bombs, it all provides a great deal of content.  The stages are partially based of the music selected, with things like weapon power & enemy variety dependent on the song.  As such, each song can provide a different experience.  The preset songs can be a bit of fun as well.  The controls are very smooth, allowing fluent movement & easy take downs of the simpler ships, yet allows the player to dodge around larger targets.  Another positive is how each different attack makes a different sound, allowing the player to be clued in on what attack is coming, & how to best deal with it.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] Geez, this game has a lot of flashing lights.  The epilepsy warning at the beginning is no joke, & for those who are sensitive to that, it can ruin your day after only a few matches.  Other than that, some of the songs can be a little tedious if they either spawn too few power ups, or too few enemies, making long form play that bounces from one song to another a gamble.  That last one really is more on the player's end than the game's, however.  Lastly, the Shadow Missions DLC is a little lackluster, with the real meat coming from the extra enemies & bosses it provides.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] This one can be a bit of a challenge, depending on reflexes, & previous knowledge with space shooters.  But once you begin leveling up your perks, a lot becomes a great deal easier.  Playing around with a few songs that you know will drop what you need is also a massive help.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Asteroids meets your music library is a wonderful match, & if you tone down some of the particle effects, it's even better.  The game has a few flaws that do take away from the core experience, but it still holds itself up on it's positive traits, moving from strength to strength to create a fun & dynamic experience on your way up the perk list.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I rate Beat Hazard 3.5/5. This is a pretty good little game. This is a music-controlled, twin-stick shooter space arcade game. The Intensity of the music track being played controls the speed at which enemies move, the rate at which your main weapon fires and the number of enemies which appear at a time. However, beyond the bright, flickering special effects and music-controlled enemy behavior, Beat Hazard actually plays a lot like the classic Atari Asteroids game (except with more enemy variety, far better controls and far better weapons).

+ This game is capable of playing any mp3 file on your computer and using that file to (at least partially) control in-game enemy behavior. This means that Beat Hazard has as many levels as you have mp3 files to play. Even better, (especially if you get the DLC content) this game features several ship types, several game modes and multiple difficulty levels. There are also several enemy types. The replay value of this arcade-style game is quite high as a result despite the fact that this game lacks any plot.

+/- The controls are highly responsive and there are no major bugs though the game’s method for binding controls is a bit tricky. Keys must be held down at the prompted times in order to bind those keys (not just tapped).

+/- A lot of this game’s challenge is coping with how busy and confused the game’s graphics can get. The amount of special effects and visual glare occurring on-screen is controlled by the intensity and tempo of the music being played at any given time. The more intense the music, the more busy the game’s visuals will be (even if the effect intensity is turned down to 50%, the game’s minimum setting). Quiet, peaceful songs are a lot easier to play through than busy, frenetic songs.

+/- DLC content is excellent and adds much needed features such as special missions to unlock different, interesting ships and large boss enemies which appear during songs. While this content is all very good, it is also all stuff that probably should have been in the base game to begin with. The bosses occasionally show up at odd times during songs (not necessarily the song’s climax) unfortunately. 

- The bright, glaring, strobing and flickering graphical effects can quickly become irritating. Beyond the music controlling the enemies’ number and movements, this becomes a game about not accidentally bumping into stuff as it becomes increasingly difficult to see what you are doing due to all the flickering flashes on screen.

- Once the novelty of the game’s central idea wears off and you get a general idea for how the game reacts to different types of music, Beat Hazard can begin to feel repetitive and eventually, stale. Using multiplayer options can decrease this feeling for a while. 

Even so, if you REALLY like listening to music like I do, Beat Hazard can be a fun little game to use while you listen to your songs if the busy, flashing graphics aren’t too much of a distraction. I’d recommend getting Beat Hazard for cheap during a steam sale and given this game’s age, finding it for cheap shouldn’t be too difficult.
